In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: WHanne that Aueryll wyth hys schoures sote . /
The droghte of marche had ꝑper/parced vn to rote /
And bathed eủer/rey veyne wyth such lycoure . /
Of whych vertu engendred is the floure .
Whan Zepherus eke with hys soote breth
Espyred haith in eủer/rey holte and heth
The tendre croppys and the yong sōmne .
Hayth in the Rāmme hys half cours y rōmne .
And smale foules maken melodye .
That slepe al nyght wᵗith open eye .
So prykceth hem nature in her corage .
Thanne longen folke to goo on pylgrymage .
And Palmers to seke straunge loundes
To serue halowys couth in sundry londys
And specyally from euery schyrys end
Of Englond to caunterbury they wende
The holy blysfull martyr for to seke .
That hem haith holpen . whan they were syke
Byfell in that sesoun vp on a day
In southwerk atte the Taberde as y lay
Redy to wynde on my pilgmage
To Caunterbury with deuoute corage .
At nyght was cōmmyn in to that hostelerye .
Wele ix and twenty in a companye .
Of sondry folk . by auenture y falle
In the feloschyp . and pylgrymes were they alle
That toward caunterbury wolde y ryde .
The chambres and the stables were wyde
And wel werēm they eesyd atte the best
And schortely whan the sōmne was go to rest .
So hadde y spoken with hem eủer/reychone .
That I was of her feloschyp anone .
And mayd forward erly / for to ryse .
To take oure wey þ̉er/re . as I ȝow deuyse .
But neủer/retheles whyle I haue tyme and space
Er that I ferther in thys tale pace .
Me thenketh hyt acordant to resoun
To telle yow all the condicyone .
Of eche of hem soo as hyt semyd me .
And whych thei were and of what degree .
And eke in what araye they weren in
And at a knyght thanne will I fyrst bigyn
A knyght þ̉er/re was and that a worthy man
That from the tyme that he first bygan
To ryden out . he louyd chyualrye
Trouth / honour / fredom / and Curtesye .
Full worthye was he in hys lordes werre .
And ther to had he ryden no man ferre .
As wele in crystendome as in hethenes
And eủer/re honoured for hys worthynes .
At Alysaundre he was whan hyt wonne .
Full ofte he had the borde bygonne .
Aboue all nacyons in pruce .
In lecto had he ryden and in Ruce .
No crysten man so oft in hys degree .
In Garnarde at the sege eke had he be .
At algazyr and ryden in belmarye .
At lyes was he and at Sattalie
Whan thei were wonne . and at the grece see
At many a noble Ryver had he be .
At mortale batailes had he ben xv .
And foghten for oure fayth in tramieshen
In lystes thryes and alway slayn hys foo .
Thys ylk worthy knyght had ben alsoo .
Sıı̄un tyme wyth the lord of palacie .
Aȝeinst a nother hethyn in Turkye .
And eủer/remore he had a souereyn prys
And thoghte that he was worthy . he was wyse .
And of porte as meke as is a mayde
He neủer/re ȝit no vylanye ne sayde
In alle hys lyfe vn to no maner wyght .
He was a verre gentyle ꝑper/parfyt knyght .
For to telle ȝow of hys array .
Hys hors was goode . but he was not gay .
Of fustian he wered a gyppioıı̄un .
Alle by smotred wyth his haburioıı̄un .
For he was late cōmmen from his vyage .
And went for to dōm hys pylgrymage .
Wyth hym ther was hys sōmne a yong squyer
A lover and a lusty bacheler
With lokkes crulled . as thei wer late īm pᵃsse .
Of . xx . ȝeer of age he was as I gesse .
Of hys stature he was of euen length
And wonderly delyủer/re and of grete strength .
And he had bene sıı̄un tyme in chyualrie
In Flaundres / in Artoys / and in pycardie .
And borne hym wele of so lytel space .
In hope to stonde in his lady grace .
Enbroudred was he as hyt were a meede .
Alle full of freshe floures whyte and reede .
Syngyng he was and floytyng all the day
He was as fresh as is the moneith of may .
Short was hys govne wyth slevys long and wyde .
Wele couthe he sytte on hors ⁊and fayr ryde .
He couthe songes make and wele endyte .
Iuste / daunce / wele portrey / and wryte .
Soo hoote he lovyd that be nyght̉er/re tale .
He slepyd nomore than doith the nyghtygale .
Curteis he was lowely and ʆser/siruyciable .
And carfe before hys fadere at the table .
A Ȝōmman had he and ʆser/siruauntez no moo .
At that tyme for hym lyst to ryde soo .
He was clad in a coote and hoode of grene .
A shef / of pecokes arowes bryȝt and shene .
Vnder hys belt he bare full thryftyly
Wele couthe he dresse hys tacle ȝōmmanly .
Hys arowes drowpyd noȝt wᵗith fethers lowe .
And in hys myghty hand he bare a bowe .
A notted heede had he wyth broune vysage .
Of wodecraft wele couthe the vsage .
Vpon hys arme he bare a gay bracere .
And by hys syde / a swerde / and a bokelere .
And vn that oþir syde a gay dagger .
Harnesyd wele . āmd sharp as poynt of spere .
A cristofore on hys brest of syluyr schene .
An horne he bare the bawdryk was of grene .
A forster was he sothely as I gesse .
THer was also a nonne pryoresse .
That of her smylyng was symple ⁊and coy
Hyre grettest othe was by seint loy
And she was clepyd ma dame Eglentyne .
Full wele she song the ʆser/siruyce dyuyne .
Entvned in her voys full semely
And frensch she spake full fayr and fetysly .
After the scole . of Stratford of the bowe .
For frensh of Parys was to her vnknowe .
At the mete wele itaught was she wᵗith all
She lete no morsell from her lyppes fall
Ne wette hir fyngres in her sauce depe .
Wele couthe she carie a morsell . ⁊and wele kepe .
That no drope fill vp on her brest .
In curtesie was sette ful myche her lest
Hyr oủer/re lyppes wyped she so clene
That in her cuppe ther was no ferthyng sene .
Of grece whan she hadde drunke hyr draught
Full semely aftyr hyr meete she raught .
And sykerly sche was of grete disporte .
And full plesaunte . and amyable of porte .
And payned hyr to countyrfete chere
Of courte . to be stately of manere .
And to holdēm dygne of Reủer/reence .
But for to speke of hyr conscience .
She was so charytable and so pytous .
She wolde wepe . ȝif she saugh a mous
Caught in a trappe . ȝef hyt were dede or blede .
Of smale houndes had she that she fedde .
Wyth roste flessh mylk or wastell brede .
But soore she wept ȝif oone of hēm were dede .
Or ȝif men smote hyt with a ȝerde smert .
And all was conscience and tendre hert .
Full semely hyr wymple pynched was .
Hyr nose streight hir eyen grey as glas .
Hyr mouthe smale and ther to soft and rede .
But sekirly she had a faire forhede .
Hyt was almost a spanne brode Itrowe .
For hardely she was not vndirgrowe .
Full fetys was hyr cloke as I was ware .
Of smale coralle aboute hir necke she bare
A pair of bedes with gaudes all of grene .
Ther on hyng a broche of golde full shene .
On whyche was wryten a crouned A .
And after Amor vincit omnia .
A nother nonne with hyr had she .
That was her chapelane . and pstes thre .
A Monke ther was a fair man for þe maistry
An out ryder that loued wele venery .
A manly man to be an abbot able .
Ful mony a deynty hors had he in stable .
And whan he rode . men myght hys bridel here .
Gynglyng and whistelyng wynde as clere .
And as lowde as doith þᵉ chapell belle .
Ther as the lord was keꝑper/par of the selle .
The Rule of seynt Maury or of seint Benet
By caus hit was olde and sudele streyt
This ilke monke let olde thynges passe .
And helde aftyr þe new worldys space
He yaffe noȝt of þᵗat text a pullyd hene .
That sayth that hunters ben noȝt holy men .
Ne that a monke . whan he is recheles
Ys likkenyd to a fyssh that is waterles .
Thys is to sey . a monk out of hys cloistr .
That ilke holde he noȝt worth an oistr .
And I seyd hys opynyon was goode .
What sholde he studie and make hym wode
Vpon a boke in Cloistr for to poore .
Or swynk with hys hondes or laboure .
As Austyn biddes how shall the worlde be seruyd .
Let Austyn haue hys swynk to hym reseruyd .
Therfore he was a prycasour a ryght
Grehoundes he had . as swyft as foule of flyȝt .
Of prykyng and huntyng for the hare
Was all his lust . for no cost wold he spare .
I saugh hys slevys purfilyd at the hand
Wyth gryse . the fyneste in a land .
And for to fastene hys hoode vndyr hys chyn
He had of gold wroȝt a curious pyn
A loue knot in the grett̉er/re ther was .
His heed was balld and shone as any glas .
And eke his face as he had ben anoynt .
He was a lord full fat and īm good poynt .
Hys eyen stepe rollyng in hys heede
That stemed as doith a fournes of lede .
Hys bootes souple . hys hors in gret state .
Certenly he was a fair prelate .
He was noȝt pale lyke a forpyned goost .
A fat swanne loued he best of any roost .
Hys palfrey was as broune as is a bery .
x frere th̉er/re was a wantou and a mery
A lymytour and a full solempne man
In all þe ordres foure is non that can
So mych of daliaunce and fair langage
He had made many a fair mariage .
Of yong wymen at hys owen proper cost
To hys ordre he was a noble post .
Full wele beloued and familier was he
Wyth frankeleyns oủer/re all in hys contre
And eke with worthy wymen of þe toune
For he had power of confessioun
As he said hy self mor þen a curate
For of his order he was licēmciate
Full sweetly did he heer confession
And plesaunt was his absolucion
He was an esy man to ȝeve penaunce
Ther as he wyst to haue a good pytaunce .
For vn to poure ordre for to ȝiffe .
Ys a signe that a man is wele yschryffe .
For ȝif he ȝaf . he durst make hys avaunt .
He wyst that a man was repentaunt .
For many a man so herd is of hert
He may noȝt wepe thogh he soore smert .
Therfore in stede of wepyng and pᵃyers
Men most ȝif siluer to the pour Freres .
His typet was ay farced full of knyves .
And pynnes . to ȝif fayr wives .
And certanly he had a mery note
Wele couthe he syng and play vpon a rote
Of ȝeddyng he bare vtterly the prys
Hys nekke was whyte as the flour delys .
Ther to strong as ony champyoun
He knew the tauerners wele in euery toun
And eủer/rey hosteler and tapster
Welbet̉er/re than a begge or a lazar .
For vn to such a man as he .
Acordetth noȝt as by hys faculte .
To haue wᵗith such lazers aqueyntaunce .
Hit is noȝt honest hyt may noȝt auᵃunce
For to dele wyth suche pouerayle .
But all wyth ryche and sellers of vytayle .
And oủer/re all other as ꝓprofyt shuld aryse .
Curteys he was and lowely of seruyse .
There was no man nowhere so vertuous
He was the best begger in hys hous .
And ȝaf a certen ferme for the grᵃunnte
None of hys bretheryn cam þ̉er/ree in hys haunte .
For thogh a vydowe had but a sho
So plesaunt was hys in principio /
There wold he haue a ferthyng or he went
Hys purchas was bett̉er/re than hys Rent .
And rage he couthe as hyt wer a whelp
In louedaies he couthe full mykell help .
For he was not lyke a cloistrere
Wyth threedbare coope as is a pour scolere .
But he was lyke a maist̉er/re or a pope .
Of double worsted was hys semy cope .
That rounded was as a belle out of þe psse .
Sıı̄unwhat he lypsed for hys wantounesse .
To make hys englyssh swete vp on hys tonge .
And in hys herpyng whan he had songe
Hys eyen twynkeled in hys heede a ryȝt .
As done sterres in the frosty nyȝt .
Thys worthy lymytour clepyd was huberd .
a merchant was there wᵗith a forked berd
In mottley on hie on hors he sat .
Vp on hys heed a flaundres beủer/re hat .
His botes clapsed fair and fetosly .
Hys resou he spak full solempnely .
Shewyng al way thencrece . of hys wynnyng .
He wold the see were kept for any thyng
Bytwyx Andelburgh and orwell
Wele couthe he in eschaunge scheldys sell .
Thys worthy man full wele hys wytte bysette .
Ther wyst no man that he was in dette .
So stately was he of goủer/renaunce .
Wyth hys bargeyns and his cheuyshaunce .
For soth he was a worthy man wyth all .
But soith to sey I not how men hym call
a Clerk ther was of Oxenford also

l.hi: That vn to logyke long had y go

div.l: And lene was he . not ryȝt fat I vndtake .
But loked holowe . and þ̉er/re to soburly
Full threede bar was hys ouerest courtby
For he getyn hym ȝit no benefice .
Uor he was noȝt worthy to haue an office .
For hym wer levir haue . at his beddys heede
XX . bokes cladde in blak and reede .
Of Arystotle and his philosophie
Than robes rych . or fidelle or savtrie
But all be hyt he was a phylosophr
Ȝit had he but lytell gold in coofr .
But all that he myȝt of hys frendes hent
On bokes and on lernyng he hit spent .
And besyly can he for the soules prey
Of hem that ȝaf hym wherwyth to scoley .
Of studie toke he most cure an hede .
Noȝt a word spake he moore than was neede .
And that was seyd in forme and reủer/reence .
And short and quyk and full of hyegh sentence .
Sounyng in morall vertu was hys spech .
Gladly wold he lerne . and gladly teche .
a Seriaunt of þe law war and wys .
That oft had bene at parvys .
Ther was also full ryche of excellence .
Discrete he was and of grete Reủer/reence .
He semyd such . hys wordes wer so wyse .
Iustice he was full oft in assise .
By patent and by plane . cōmmission .
For hys science and hys renoun .
Of fees and robes he had mony oone
So grete a purchasour was nowher noone .
All was fee symple to hym in effecte .
Hys purchasyng myȝt not be infecte .
Nowhere so besy a man ther nas
And ȝit he semed bysier than he was .
In termes had he cas and domes all
That from the tyme of kyng william was fall .
Therto he couth endite and mak a thyng .
Ther couth no wyȝt pynch at hys endityng
And eủer/rey statute couth he pleyn by roote .
He roode but homely in a medley coote .
Gyrt wyth a seynt of sylk wyth barres smale .
Of hys araye telle I no lenger tale .
A Frankelene ther was in hys cıı̄unpany .
White was hys berd as is the daieseye .
Of hys complexciou he was sanguyne .
Wele loued in the morn a soppe in wyne .
To lyue in delyte was eủer/re hys wone .
For he was Epicurius owne sone .
That held opiniou that verrey delyte .
Was verily felicite parfyte .
An housholder and that a grete was he .
Seint Iulian he was in hys contre .
Hys breede his ale was alway aft̉er/re one .
A bett̉er/re enuyned man was no wher none .
Wyth out bake mete was neủer/re hys hous .
Of fysh and flessh and that so plentivous .
Hyt snewed in hys hous of mete and drynk
Of all deintes that men couth on thynk .
After the sondry sesouns of the ȝer
So chaungeith he hys mete and hys soper .
Full many a fat ꝑper/partryche had he in mewe .
And many a breme and many a luce īm stewe .
Woo was hys cooke . but ȝif hys sauce were .
Poynant and sharp and redy all hys gere .
Hys table dormaunt in hys all alwey
Stode redy couered all the long day .
At the sessions there was he lord and syr .
Full oft had he bene knyght of the schyr .
An anlas on a gypcer all of sylk .
Hyng vn hys gyrdell whyte as morowe mylke .
A shyreue had he bene and a countour .
Was nowhere suche a nother vauasour .
An haburdassher . and a carpent̉er/re .
A Webbe . a Dier . and Tapycer .
Thei were clothed all in oo lyuer .
Of a solempne and a grete fraternite .
Full fressh and newe her ger pyked was
Her knyves chaped wer noȝt of glas .
But wroȝt wyth sylủer/re al full clene and wele .
Her gyrdels and her pouches eủer/reydele .
Wele semed ech of hem a fair burgeis
To sitte in þe ȝeld halle on a deis .
Eủer/reyche for the wysdom that he kan
Was shapely to be an alder man .
For catell had þei ynogh and Rent .
And eke her wyves wolde hit wele assent .
And elles certen thei weren to blame .
Hyt is full fair to be clepyd ma dame .
And go to vigiles all to forne
And haue a mantel ryale born .
a Cook thei had wᵗith hem for the nones
To boyle the chykens wᵗith the merybones .
And poudre / marchant tart / and galymgale
Wele couthe he know a draught of londou ale .
He couth rost ⁊and bole . seth and frie .
Make mortreux and wele bake a pye .
But grete harme was hit as hit thoght me .
That on his chynne a mormal had he .
For blankmanger maide he wᵗith the best .
a schypman was ther wonnyng th̉er/re by west .
For ought I woote he was of dertemouth .
He roode on a Rouncy as he couthe .
In a gowne of faldyng to the kne .
A dagger hangyng on a lace had he .
Aboute hys nekke vnd hys arme a done .
The hoote somer had made . his hew al brone .
And certanly he was a goode felaw
Full many a draugh of wyne had he draw .
From bordeux ward whilest the mchantez slepe .
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe .
Ȝif that he fawght and had the herre hond
By water he sendt them home by eủer/rey lond .
But of hys craft to rykene wele hys tydes
Hys stremys and hys daungers hym besydes
Hys herburgh and hys money and hys lodmanage .
Ther nas no man suche from Hull vn to Cartage .
Herdy he was and wyse to vndertake .
Wyth many a tempest had hys berd be shake .
He knew all the hauenes as thai ware
From scotland vn to the lond of fenestar
And eủer/rey cryke in brytaigne and in spaigne .
Hys barge was clepyd þe maudeleyne .
wyth vs ther was a maister of fysyk
In all the world was non hym lyke .
To speke of fysyk and of Surgerye .
For he was grounded in astronomye .
He kept hys pacient a full grete dele
In houres by hys magyk naturele .
Wele couthe he fortune the ascendent .
Of hys ymage for hys pacient .
He knew the caus of eủer/rey maladie .
Were hit hoote . colde . moist . or drye .
Where hit engendreth and of what humour .
He was a verrey parfyt practysour .
The cause he knew and of hys harme þᵉ rote .
Anon he ȝaf the seke man hys bote .
Full redy had he his apotecaries .
To send hym dragges . and his letuaries
For eche of hem maide oth̉er/re to wynne .
Here frendeschyp was noȝt new to bygynne .
Wele knew he the old Esculapius .
Dioscorides and eke Ruphus
Olde ypocᵃs . haly . and galien
Serapion . Razy . and Auicen
Aủer/reoys . damascien . and constantyn .
Bernard . Gatisden . and gilbertyn .
Of his diete mesurable was he .
For hit was of no suꝑper/parfluyte .
But of grete noryshyng ⁊and digestible .
His studie was but lytell on the bible .
In sanguyne and in pers clad was he all
Lyned with taffata and wyth sendall .
And ȝit he nas but esy of dispence .
He kept that he wan in pestylence .
For gold in fysyk is a cordial .
Ther for he loued gold in specyal .
a good wyf th̉er/re was of besydes bathe .
Sche was su dele deffe . ⁊and þᵗat was scathe .
Of clothe makyng had she such haunt
She passed hem of ypres and of Gaunt
In all the parysh wyf was þ̉er/re none .
That to the offeryng before hyr shuld gone .
And ȝif þer dyd certen so wrothe was she .
That she was out of all charite .
Hyr keuerches full fyne were of grounde .
I durste swer thei weyed x pounde .
That on a sounday were on her heede .
Hyre hosen of fyne scarlet Rede .
Full streit y tied . and shone full moist and newe .
Bold was her face and fayr and reede of hewe .
She was a worthy wōmman all hyr lyue .
Housbondes at churche dore had she fyue .
Wythoute other cumpany in ȝouthe .
But þ̉er/reof nedeth noȝt to speke as nouthe .
And thries had she bene at Ierm .
She had passed mony a strong streme .
At Rome she had be and at Boloigne .
In Galeis at saint Iagnes and at Coloigne .
She couthe muche of wandryng by þe wey
Gattetothed was she sothely to sey
Vp on an ambeler esyly she satte .
Ywympled wele and on heed an hatte .
As brode as is a bokeler or a targe .
A foote mantell aboutes her large .
Vp on hyr feete a pair of spores sharp .
In felaschyppe wele couthe laugh and carpe .
Of remedie of loue sche couthe ꝑper/parchaunce .
For she knew of that olde daunce .
A good man ther was of Religione .
and was a pour ꝑper/parsoun of a toun
But ryche he was of holy thoght ⁊and werk .
He was also a lernyd man . ⁊and a clerk .
That crystes gospell truly wolde preche .
Hys parysshins deuoutly wolde he teche .
Benygne he was and wonder diligent
And in aduersite full pacient .
And suche he was proued oft sythes
For lothe were hym to curse for hys tithes .
But raith̉er/re wolde he ȝif hit out of doute .
Vn to hys poủer/re parishins aboute .
Of hys offryng and of hys substance .
He couthe in lytell thyng haue suffisaunce
Wyde was hys parisshe . and houses fer a sondre .
But he ne left neyther for reyn ne thondre .
In sekenes nor in myschef to visite .
The ferrest in hys paryssh muche ⁊and lyte .
Vp on hys feet and on hys hond a staffe .
This noble ensample vn to hys shepe he ȝaffe .
That fyrst he wroȝt and afterward he taught .
Out of the gospell the wordes he caught .
This figure eke he added þ̉er/re to .
That ȝif gold ruste what shall yren do ;
For ȝif a pste be foule . in whome we trust .
No wonder is a lewde man to rust .
And schame hit is . ȝif a pst take kepe .
A schyten sheꝑper/pard and a clene shepe .
Wele ought a sheꝑper/pard ensample for to ȝiffe .
By hys clennesse how hys shepe shulde lyffe .
He sette noȝt his benefice to hyre .
And leueth his shepe acombred in þᵉ myre .
And ran to londou vn to seint poules
To sechen hym a chart̉er/re for soules .
Or with a bretherhede to be with holde .
But dwellyd at home ⁊and kept wele his folde .
Soo that the wolf ne maide it noȝt myscarie
He was a sheꝑper/pard and noȝt a mcennarie .
And thogh he holy were and vertuous
He was noȝt to synfull men dispitous .
Ne of speche dangerous ne digne .
But in his techyng discrete ⁊and benigne .
To drawen folk to heuen by fairnesse
By good ensample thys was his bisynesse .
But hit were any ꝑper/parson obstinate .
What so he were of hiegh or lowe astate .
Hym wold he snobbe sherply for the nones .
A bettyr prest I trowe that nowhere non es .
He wayted aft̉er/re no pompe and reủer/reence .
Ne maked hym a spiced conscience .
But cristes lore and his apostles twelue
He taught . but first he folowed hy selue .
Wyth hym th̉er/re was a plowman was his brother
That hadde yladde of dong full many a fother .
And a trew swynker and a good man was he
Leuynge in pees and ꝑper/parfite charite .
God loued he best wyth all his hert .
At all tymes thogh he gamed or smert .
And than his neigheboure . ryȝt as hym self .
He wolde thresse and þ̉er/re to dyke and delf
For cristes sake for eủer/rey poure wyght
Wit outen her . if hit lay in his myght .
His tithes payed he full fair and wele .
Bothe of his ꝓpropre swynk and catele .
In a taberd he roode vpon a meere .
There was also a reef and a myllere .
A sompnoᵘur and a ꝑper/pardoner also .
A manciple and my self þ̉er/ree wer no mo .
The myllere was a stoute carle for þe nones
Ful byg he was of brawne ⁊and eke of bones .
That proued wele . for oủer/re all ther he came .
At wrastelyng he wold haue the Rame .
He was schuldred short . a thykke knarre .
There was no dore that he nold hevyn of barre .
Or breke it at a rennynge wyth hiz hed .
Hys berd as any sowe or fox was red .
And þ̉er/reto broode as thogh hit wer a spade
Vppon the coppe on hys nose he hade
A wert . and þ̉er/re on stode a tuft of herys .
Reede as the brystles of a sowes eyrys .
Hys nose thrylles blake were and wyde
A swerd and a bokeler bare he by hys syde .
Hys mouthe as grete was as a gʳte fourneys
He was a iangler and a galierdeis
And that moost of syn and of harlottries .
Wele couthe he stele corn ⁊and tolle thries .
And ȝit he had a thombe of gold perde .
A white coote and a blewe weryd he .
A bagge pype wele couthe he blow and sown .
And þ̉er/re wyth all he broght vs oute of towne .
A gentyll manciple was ther of the temple .
Of whiche all catours myght take ensample .
For to bene wyse in byeng of vytale .
For whethyr that he payd or toke by tayle .
Algate he wayted so in hys acate
That he was ay beforn ⁊and in goode state .
Now is not that of god a full fayre grace
That suche a lewyd māmnes wytte shall pace
The wysdom of an hepe of lernyd men ;
Of maistres had he mo than thries ten
That were of law expert ⁊and curious .
Of whyche ther was a dosan in that hous
Worthy to ben stywardes of Rent ⁊and lande
Of any lorde that is in englande .
To make hym lyf by hys ꝓpropre goode
In honour detteles but yf that he wer woode .
Or lyf als streitley as hym lyst desire
And able for to helpyn all a shyre .
In any case that mygte falle or happe .
And ȝit this manciple sette her aller cappe .
The Refe was a slendre coleryk man .
Hys berd was shafe as nygh as eủer/re he can .
Hys here was by hys erys full rounde y shorne .
Hys toppe was dokked lyk a prest byforne .
Full long were his legges and full lene .
Ylyke a staffe ther was no calf y sene .
Wele couthe he kepe a garner or a bynne .
There was no auditour couthe on hym wynne .
Wele wist he by the droghte and by the reyne .
The ȝeldyng of hys seed and of hys greyne .
Hys lordes shepe . hys nete hys deyry .
Hys swyn . hys horse . hys stoure . ⁊and his pultry
Was hooly in thys Refes gouernyng .
And by his covenaunt yaf hym rekenyng
Syn that hys lord was . xx . ȝeere of Age .
There couth no man bryng hym in arrerage
Ther was ballyf . ne hyrde . nor other hyne .
That he ne knew hys sleight and hys covyne .
Thei were adred of hym as of the deith .
Hys wonnyng was full fayre vp on an heith .
Wyth grene trees shadowed was hys place .
He couth better than hys lord purchace .
Full ryche he was a stored pⁱriuely
Hys lord he couth wele plesen subtely .
To ȝif hym and lene hym of hys owne goode .
And haue a thank and ȝit a coote and an hode .
In ȝouth he had lernyd a goode mystery
He was awele good wryght of carpentry
Thys Refe sat vp on a wele good stot
That was pomell gray and hight scotte
A long surcot of peers vppon he hadde
And by hys syde he bare a rusty blade .
Of Northfolk was thys Refe of whyche y telle
Bysyden a towne . men clepyn hyt Bladeswell .
Tukked he was as is a frere aboute
And euery he rode the hyndrest of our route .
A sompnour was ther wᵗith vs in place
That had a fayr cherubynnes face .
For savsfleme he eyen narowe
As hoote he was and lycherous as a sparowe
Wyth scalled browes . blake and pyled berde
Of hys vysege children wer aferde .
Ther nas quyk syluer . lytargie . or bromston
Boras orsure ne oyle of tartre noone .
Ne oynement that wold clense or byte
That hym myght help of hys whelkes whyte .
Nor of hys knobbes syttynge in hys chekes .
Wele louyd he garlek onȝons and eke lekes .
And for to drynk strong wyn reede as blode
Than wolde he crie and speke as he wer woode .
And whan that he wele dronken had the wyne .
Than wolde he speke no word but latyne .
A fewe termes had he two or thre .
That he had lernyd oute of su decre .
No wondre is . he herd hit all day .
And eke ȝe knowen hit wele / how that a Iay
Kan clepe watte . as wele as can the pope .
But who so couth in oth̉er/re thyngꝭes hym groope
Than had he spend all his philosophie
Ay questio quid Iuris . wold he crye .
He was a gentyll harlot and a kynd .
A bett̉er/re felaw shuld no man fynde .
He wold suffre for a quarte of wyne
A good felaw to haue hys concubyne
A twelf moneith . and excuse hym at fulle
Full pryvely eke a fynche couthe he pulle .
And yf he founde owhere a good felawe .
He wolde teche hym to haue noon awe .
In suche cas of the archedekyns curse .
But yf māmnes soule were in hys purse .
For in hys purse punyshed he shuld be
Purse is the archedekyns helle seyd he .
But wele I wote . he lyhede ryȝt in dede
Of cursyng oughte ych gilty man hym drede .
For curse will sle ryȝt as assoylyng sauyth
And also ware hym of a significauit .
In daunger had he at his owne gyse
Two yong gerles of the diocise
And knew her councele and what was all rede .
A garland had he sette vp on his hede
As grete as hit were for an hale stake .
A bokeler had he made hym of a cake .
Wyth hym there rode a gentyll ꝑper/pardoner
Of Rouncyuale hys frend and hys compere .
That streight was cōmmyn fro the courte of Rome .
Full lowde he song . come hyder love to me .
Thys sompnoᵘur bare to hym a styffe burdou .
Was neủer/re trıı̄unpe of half so grete a sown
This ꝑper/pardoner had here as ȝelow as wax
But smoth hit hyng as doith a stryk of flax .
By vnces hang hys lokkes that he hadde .
And ther wyth hys shuldres oủer/re spradde .
But thynne hit lay by culpons oone ⁊and oon
But hode for iolyte weryd he none .
For hit was trussed vp in his walet
Hym thoght he roode all of new get
Discheueled saf hys cappe he roode all bare .
Wyth glaryng eyen had he as an hare .
A veronycle had he sewyd vppon his cappe .
Hys walet beforne hym in his lappe .
Bret full of ꝑper/pardou cōmmen from Rome all hote .
A voys he had als smale as any gote .
No berd had he . ne neủer/re shuld haue .
As smothe hit was as hit were late shaue .
I trow he wer a geldyng or a mare .
But of his craft from Berwyk in to ware .
Ne was ther such anoth̉er/re ꝑper/pardonere .
For in his male he had a pylowere .
Whych that seid was our ladys veile .
He seyde he had a gobbet of the seyle .
That seint pet̉er/re had when þᵗat he weynt
Vppon þᵉ see . tyll Ihu cryst hym hent .
He had a croys of latou full of stones
And in a glas he had pigges bones
But wyth these relykes whan that he fonde
A poure ꝑper/parsou duellyng vppon londe .
Vppon a day he gate more money
Than that the ꝑper/parsoıı̄un gate in monethes tweye .
And thus wyth feyned flateryng ⁊and iapes
He maide the ꝑper/parsou and the peple his apes .
But truly to tellen at the last
He was in church a noble ecclesiast .
Wele couth he reede a lessou or a story
But alderbest he song an offertory .
For wele he wyst . whan that song was song .
He moost pche and welle affyle hys tong .
To wynne sylủer/re as he wele cowde .
Therfore he song so meryly and lowde .
¶ Now haue ytolde sothely in a clause .
The estat . the array . the nombre . ⁊and eke the cause .
Why that assembled was thys cumpany
In southwerk at this gentyll hostery .
That hyght the taberd fast by the belle .
But now is tyme yow for to telle
How that baryn vs that ylke nyght
Whan that were in that Ostelery alyght .
And after wylle y telle of oure viage .
And all the remanaunt of oure pylgⁱmage .
But ferst y pᵃy ȝow of your curtesie .
That ȝe ne rette hit noȝt my vilanye .
Thogh that I planely speke in þis mater
To telle ȝow her wordes and her chere .
Ne thogh y speke her wordes ꝓpropurly
For this ȝe knowen as wele as I .
Who so shall tellen a tale aft̉er/re a man
He moot reherse as neygh as eủer/re he can
Eủer/reyche a worde yf hit be in hys charge .
Al speke he neủer/re so rudely and large .
Or elles he mote telle his tale vn trew
Or feyne thynges or fynde wordes newe .
He may noȝt spare all thogh he wer his brother .
He moote as wele sey oo worde as an other .
Cryst spake hym self full broode in holy wrytte .
And wele ȝe wote no vylanye is hitte .
Eke plato seith . who so can hym reede .
The wordes moote be cosyn to the dede .
Also y pᵃy ȝow for ȝif hit me .
All though y sette not folk in her degre
Here in this tale as that thei shuld stonde .
My wytte is shorte . ȝe may wele vndstonde .
¶ Grete chere made oure ost vs ev̉er/reychon .
And to the soper sette he hus anoone .
He serued vs wyth vytales at the best
Strong was the wyne . and wele drynken vs leste .
A semely man oure oost was wᵗith all
For to bene a mshall in an halle
A large man he was wyth eyen stepe .
A fayr burgeis is noon in chepe .
Bolde of his speche ⁊and wyse ⁊and wele ytaught .
And of manhode hym lakked ryȝt noȝt .
Eke þ̉er/reto he was right a mery man .
And after soper pleyen he bygan .
And spake of myrth among oth̉er/re thynges .
Whan that we had made oure rekenynges .
And seid thus . now lordes trewly
Ȝe ben to me welcome right hertily .
For by my trouth . yf that I shall not lye .
I see not this ȝeere so mery a cumpanye .
At oones in this herber as is now .
Fayne wold y done ȝow merth . wyst I how .
And of a myrthe I am ryght now by thoght .
To done ȝow eese . and hit shall cost ȝow noght .
Ȝe goone to Canterbury god ȝow spede .
Þe blysfull martir quyte ȝow youre mede .
And wele I wote as ȝe gone by the waye
Ȝe shappen ȝow to talen ⁊and to pleye .
For truly comforth ne myrth is noone .
To ryden by the way dombe as a stone .
And þerfore will I maken disport
As I seid erst and done ȝow some comfort .
And yf hit lyke ȝow by oone assent
For to stonden at my Iuggement .
And for to werken as I shall ȝow say
To morwe whan ye ryden by the way .
Now by my fader soule that is dede .
But ȝe be mery I will ȝiffe ȝow my hede .
Holde vp ȝoure handes wyth oute more speche .
Oure councele was not long to seche .
Vs thoght hit was not worth to make ws wyse .
And gᵃunted hym wyth oute more avyse .
And herd hym sey hys veordyte as hym lest .
Lordynges quod he now herkeneth for the best .
But taken hit noght y pᵃye ȝow in disdeigne .
This is the poynt to speke shorte and pleigne .
That eche of ȝow to shorte wyth oure weye
In this viage shall telle tale tweye .
To canterbury warde I mene hit so .
And homwardes he shall tellen oth̉er/re two .
Of auentours . that whilom haue byfalle .
And whiche of ȝow . that berys hym best of alle
That is to seyn . that telleth in þis cas
Tales of most sentence ⁊and most solas
Shall haue a soper at oure aldercost
Here in this place sittyng by this post
Whan that cōmmyn aȝen fro Canturbury
And for make ȝow the moore mery .
I wyll my self goodely wᵗith ȝow ryde .
Ryght at my owne cost and be your gyde .
And who so wyll my iuggement wythsey .
Shall pay all that we spend by the wey
And yf ȝe vochesaue that hit be soo .
Tell me a noon wyth outen wordes moo .
And y will erly shape me therfore .
This thyng was graunted ⁊and oure othes swore .
With full gladde hert ⁊and prayen hym also .
That he wold vochesaue for to do soo .
And that he wold be oure gouernour .
And of our tales iugge and reportour .
And sette a soper at a certen prys
And we willen reulyd be at hys devys .
In hiegh ⁊and lowe and thus by his assent
We ben acorded to the iuggement .
And ther vppon the wyn was fet anoon .
We dronchen and went to rest ychoon .
Wyth outen any long taryinge .
Amorow whan the day gan to sprynge
Vp rose oure oste and was oure alder cok .
And gaderde vs to gedyr in a flok .
And forth we ryden a lytell more than a pas
Vn to the wateryng of seynt Thomas .
And ther oost gan hys horse arest
And seid lordes herkenyth yf ȝow lyst .
Ȝe wote youre forwarde . and I ȝoᵘ hit recorde .
If euynsong ⁊and morowesong acorde .
Late se now who shall tell the fyrst tale .
As eủer/re mote I drynk wyn or ale .
Who so be rebell to my iuggement
Shall pay for all that by the wey is spent .
¶ Now draw þe cut . or that we ferther twynne
Whyche that hatth þe shortest / shall be gynne .
Syr knyght quod he my maist̉er/re and my lorde .
Now drawyth cut . for that is myn acorde .
Comyth nere . qd he . my lady prioresse .
And ȝe ʆser/sir Clerk . lat be youre shamefastnesse .
Ne studyeth noȝt . lay hond to euery man .
Anon to drawyth euery wyght began .
As shortely to tellen as hit was
Were hit be auenture . or sort . or cas .
The soith is . the cut fylle to the knyght .
Of whyche full blythe and glad was eủer/rey wight .
And tellen as hit was reason
By forward and by composiciou
As ȝe han herd . whitt nedyth wordes mo ;
And than this good man saugh that it was so .
As he that wyse was and obedient
To kepen his forward by his free assent .
He seyd sithen y shall begynne the game .
What welcome be the cut a goddes name .
Now late vs ryde and herkenyth what I sey .
And wyth that worde we ryden forth our wey .
And he byganne with ryȝt a mery Chere .
His tale anon . and seid as ȝe may here .

l.hi: Iamque domos patrias et cetera Post asperagentis prelia laurigero et cetera

div.l: (base) Here bigynneth / the knyghtes tale
(base) c incipit fabula Militis ;
(base) Iamque domos patria Scithice post asꝑper/para gentis laurigero etc Here bigynneth the knygtis tale
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita
(base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle

(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour

(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
Whan that the knyght thus his tale itolde
In all the company was ther yong ne olde
That he ne seid it was a noble storye
And worthy to be draw in memorie .
And namelyche the gentles euerychon .
Oure oost loghe ⁊and swore by seynt Iohn
This goth a ryght vnbokeled is the male .
Late se now who shall telle an other tale .
For truly the game is wele bygon
Now telle ȝe ʆser/sir monk yf ȝe . con
Somwhat to quyte with the knyghtes tale .
The myller that for dronk was all pale .
So that vnneith vppon his hors he satte .
He wolde availe neithor hoode . ne hat
Ne abide no man for his curteisie .
But in pilates voys he gan to crie .
And swore by armes ⁊and blode ⁊and bones
I con a noble tale for the nones
With whiche I will quyte the knyghtis tale
Oure oost sawe that he was dronk of ale .
And seid abide Robyn . leve brother
Som better man shall telle . vs first a nother
Abyde and late vs wirke thryftely
By goddes soule qd he that will not I .
For y will speke . or elles go my wey
Oure oost answerd sey on deuel wey
Thow ert a foole . thy witte is oủer/recomyn .
Now herkeneth qd the myller all ⁊and som .
But first I make . a ꝓprotestacion .
That I am dronk y knowe . hit by the soune .
And þerfore ȝif I mysspeke . or say
Wyte hit the ale of southwerk I ȝoᵘ pray
For I will telle . a legende . and a lyf
Both of a carpenter and of his wyf
How that a clerk the wright can cappe .
The Reve answerd ⁊and seyd stynt thy clappe .
Lete be thy lewed dronken harlottrye .
Hit is a synne and eke gret folye .
To appeyren . any man or hym diffame .
And eke to bryngen wyfes in suche name .
Yow maist ynogh of other thynges seyn .
This dronken myller spake full sone ageyn .
And seyd leve brother oswald .
But I sey not therfore that þow ert oone .
Ther bene full goode wyfes mony oone /
Why ert yow angry with my tale now
I haue a wyf ꝑper/parde as wele . as thow
Ȝet wold for the oxen in my plowe .
Take vppon me . more þan ynowe .
As demen on my self that I. were one .
I wold beleve that I name . noone .
An housbond shall not be . inquisityf
Of goddys pryuety ne of his wyf
So he may fynden good foyson . there .
Of the remanaunt nedith not to enquere .
What shuld . sey I more but the myller
He nolde his wordes for no man forbere .
But tolde his cherlys tale . in his maner
Me forthenketh that I shall reherse hit here .
And therfore euery gentil wyght I praye .
Demeth not for goddes love that I saye
Of euell entent but for I mote reherse .
Her tales all be the better or werse .
Or ellys faile som of my mater
And therfore who so list not hit here
Turne ouer the leef and chese a nother tale
For ȝe shull fynd ynow grete and smale .
Of historiale thyng that toucheth gentylnesse
And eke moralite and holynesse
Blame not me ȝif that ȝe chese . amysse .
The myller is a churle . ȝe know wele thys
So was the Reue . eke and other moo .
And harlottrye thei tolde both twoo .
Avyse ȝow and put me . out of blame .
And eke men shall not make ernest of game .
Whilom ther was duellyng in oxenforde .
A riche choffe that gestes held to borde
And of his craft he was a carpentere
With hym ther was dwellyng a pouer scoler
Had lerned Arte but all his fantasie .
Was turned for to lerne astrologie .
And coude a certen of conclusions
Ȝif that men axed hym in certen howres
Whar that men shuld haue drought of shoures
Or ȝif men axed hym what shuld be falle .
Of euery thyng I may not reken alle .
This clerk was clepyd hend Nicholas .
Of derne love and pryuey solas
And ther to he was . sleigh and full pⁱriuey
And lyke to a mayde meke for to sey
A chambre had he in that hostelerye .
Allone with outen any companye .
Full swete . dighte with erbes swote .
As he hym self as sote as is the rote .
Or licorice . or any situale .
His almagest and bokes grete ⁊and smale .
His augrym stones leyn . full fair a part
On shelves covched . at his beddys heed .
His prasse y couered with a faldyng reede .
And all aboue ther lay a gay sautarie
On whiche he mayde . on nyght melodie
So swetely that all the chambr rong
And angelus ad virginem he song
And after that he song the kynges note .
Full ofte blissed was his mery throte .
And thus the swete clerk his tyme spent
After his frendes fyndyng and his rent
This carpenter had weddyd new a wyf
Whiche that he loued more than his lyf
Of xviij ȝere she was of age .
Ielous he was and kept her streite in cage .
For she was wylde and ȝong ⁊and he was olde .
And demed hym self to lyke a cokewolde
He knew not catou for his was rude .
That bad men shuld wedde hir similitude
Men shuld wedde after her estate
For ȝouthe and elde is oft at debate
But sith that he was fallen in the snare .
He most enduren as other folke his care .
Fare was the yong wif and ther with smale .
As any wesel . hir body gent ⁊and smale
A seynt she weryd barred all of sylke .
A barme clothe as white . as mylke .
Vppon her lendes full of mony a gore
White was her smoke and enbrouded al before .
And eke behynd on her coler behynde aboute
Of cole blak sylk with in ⁊and eke with oute .
The tayes of her white volypere .
Were of the same suyte . of her coler
Hir filet brode of sylk and sette . full hie
And sekerly she had a lecherous eye .
Full smale y pulled were her browes two .
And tho were bent and blake as any slo .
She was full more blysfull for to see .
Than is the new perget tree .
And softer than is the wolle of a wethir
And by her purs gerdell hyng a purs of lether
Tasseld with silk and perled with latoıı̄un
In alle this worlde to speke vp and doun
Ther is no man so wyse . that couthe thenke .
So gay / a poplot or a wenche .
Full bright was the shynyng of her hewe
Than in the toure the noble forged newe .
But of hir song it was as loude and ȝerne
As any swalow sittyng on a berne .
Ther to she coude . skyppe and make a game .
As any / kidde or calfe . folowyng his dame .
Her mouthe was swete . as bragot or the methe .
Or horde of appels leyd in hey or hethe .
Wynsyng she was as is a ioly colt
Long as a mast and vpward as a bolt
A broche she bare . on her love coler
As broode as is the boos of a bokeler
Her shoes were lasyd on hir legges hye .
She was a prymplot a pygges nye .
For any lord to liggen in his bedde .
Or ȝet for any ȝōmman . to wedde .
Now sir and eft sir and so byfell that caas
That on a day this hynde nycolas
Folowith this yong wyf for to rage and play
Whyle that hir housbond was at Osney
As clerkes bene full subtel . and full queynte
And pryuely he cauȝt be the queynte .
And seyd I wys but if I haue my wille .
For derne love of the lēmman I spylle .
And held her fast by the hanche bones
And seid lēmman love me at ones
Or I will deye as god me safe
And she sprong as a colt in a trafe
And with her heed she wreied fast awaye
She seid I will not kysse the by my faye .
Whi late be qd she late be Nicholas
Or I will crie . oute harow and alas
Do wey ȝour hondes for ȝour curtesie .
This nycolas . gan mercy for to crie .
And spake so faire ⁊and ꝓprofred hym full fast .
That she her love . graunted hym at the last
And swore . his othe by seint Thomas of kent
That she wold bene . at his cōmmaundment
Whan that she may her laiser wele aspie
Myn housbond is full of ielousie .
That but ȝe wote wele but if hit be pⁱriuey
I wote ryght wele . I am but ded qd she .
Ȝe mote bene . full derne . as in this caas .
Nay therof care ȝow nought qd Nicholas
A clerke had litherly bysette . his whyle
But ȝif he coude a carpent̉er/re begile
And thus thei . acorden and sworne .
To awayte a tyme as I haue seid beforne .
Whan Nycolas . had don this euery dele
And thakkyd her aboute the lendes wele .
He kissed her swete . and takyth his sautarye
And pleith fast and maketh melodie .
Than fille hit thus that to parisshe chirch
Cristes owne werkes to wirche
This good wif vppon an halyday
Her forhede shone . as bryȝt as any day
So was hit wessh whan she left her werke .
Now was ther of the chirche a parissh Clerke .
The whiche was clepyd Absolon
Crulle was his hede . as the gold hit shone
And strouted as a fanne large ⁊and brode .
Full streite and euen lay his . ioly shoode
His rody was rede his eyen gray as . a goos
With poules wyndowes coruen in his shoos
In hosen reed he went fetisly
Ycladde he was full smalle . and ꝓpropurly
Alle in a kertell of lyght wachette .
Full faire ⁊and thikke ben the poyntes sette .
And ther vppon . he had a gay surplice
As white as is the blossome . on rys
A mery child he was so god me save .
And make a chartre of lond or a quytance
In twenty maners coude he tryppe ⁊and daunce
After the scole . of Oxenforde thoo .
And with his legges castyng to ⁊and fro
And playn songes on a smale rybible
Som tyme he song a loude quynyble
And as wele coude he pley on a gytterne .
In all the towne . was brewhous ne tauerne
That he ne wist with his solas
Ther any gaylard tapster was
But sothe to seyn . he was some dele squaymous
Of fartyng and of speche daungerous
This absalon . that was ioly and gay
Goth with a sensure on the sounday
Sensyng the wyfes of the parysshe faste
And many a louely look on hem he caste
And namely on the carpent̉er/re wyf
To loke on her he thought a mery lyf
She was so ꝓpropur and swete . ⁊and likerous
I dar wele and she had bene a movs
And he a catte he wolde her hente anoon
This paryssh clerke this ioly absalon
Haith in his hert suche a love longyng
That of no wyfe toke he no offeryng
For curtesie he seid he wolde noon
The mone whan hit was nyght bryght shone
And Absolon his gyterne haith take
For ꝑper/paramours he thoght for to awake .
And forth he goith ielous and amerous
Till he come to the carpent̉er/re hous
A litell after the coke had I craw
And dressid hym vnder a shote wyndow
That was vppon the carpent̉er/re walle
He syngeth in his vois gentill ⁊and smale .
Now dere lady ȝif thi will be
I pᵃy ȝow that ȝe rewe on me
Full wele acordyng to his geternyng
This carpenter awoke ⁊and herd hym syng
And spake vnto his wyf and seid anone .
What Alison heres thow not absolon .
That chaunteth thus vnder oure boures walle
And she ansuerd hir housbond ther with alle
Ȝey god woote Iohn I here hit euery dele
This passith forthe what will ȝe than but wele
Fro day to day this ioly Absolon .
So wowith her that hym is woo bygou
He waketh all nyght and alle the day
He kembys his lokes brode ⁊and made hem gay
He wowith her by menes and brocage .
And swore he wolde be her owne page
He syngith brokkyng as a nyghtyngale
He sent her pyment meth and spysed ale .
And wafres pypyng hoote oute of the glede .
And for she was of toun he ꝓprofered mede .
For some folk wole be wōmnyn for richesse .
And some for strokes ⁊and some for gentilnesse
Som tyme to shewen his lightnesse ⁊and maistrie
He pleyeth herawdes vpon a Scaffold hiegh
But what availeth hym in this caas
So louyth she this hēmnd Nicholas
That absolon may blow the bukeshorn
He ne had for his labour but a scorne
And thus she maketh absolon her ape
Alle his hernest turneth but to a Iape
For sothe this ꝓprouerbe hit is not to lye
Men seyn thus alwey the nyght flie .
Maketh the feer love to be loth
For þogh that absolon be woode or wrogh
Bycaus that he ferre was from hir sight
This nyght Nycolas stoode in his light
Now bere ȝow wele hend Nicholas
For absolon may syng and wele alas
And so byfell hit on a saturday
This carpenter was gone to osney
And hend nycholas and Alison
Acorded were to this conclusion
That nicholas shall shapen hym a while
This sely ielous housbond to be gile
And ȝif so be the game went a ryght
She shuld slepe in his arme all nyght
For this was his desire and hirs also .
And ryght anone with out wordes mo .
This nycholas no lenger wold tary
But doth full soft vn to his chambre cary
Both mete ⁊and drynk for a day or twey
And to her housbond bad he hir to sey
Ȝif that he asked after nycolas
She shuld sey she nyst where he was
Of all that day she saugh hym not with eye
She trowed he was in malodie .
For no crie hir mayde cowde calle
He nold ansuere for noȝt that myght byfalle .
This passith forth all the Saturday
That nycholas stille in his bedde lay
And ete and slepe and what hym lyst
Till sounnday that the sōmne goth to reste .
This sely carpenter haith grete mervaile .
Of nycholas or what thyng myght hym ayle .
And seid I am a dred by seint Thomas
Hit stondith noȝt a ryght with nycholas
God shilde that he deid sodenly
This worlde is now fikell sykerly
I saugh to day a corps borne to chirche .
That now on monnday last I sawe hym wirche
Go vp qd he to his knaue anone .
Clepe at his dore or knok wᵗith a stone .
Looke how hit is and telle me boldely
This knaue went hym vp full stordely
And at the chamber while that he stoode .
He cried and knokked as þogh he were woode .
What how what do ȝe . maist̉er/re nycholay
How may ȝe slepen all this long day
But all for noȝt he herd neuer a worde .
A borde he fonde full lowe vnder a bede .
There as the catte was wonte to crepe .
And at the hoole he loked in full depe
And at the laste he had of hym a syght
This nycholas satte euer gapyng vp ryght
As he had kekyd on the newe mone .
A done he goth and tolde his maister sone .
In what array he saugh this ilke mane .
This carpenter to blysse hym begane .
And seid help hus seint Fridesswide
A man wote litell what shall hym betyde
This man is fallen with his astronomye
In some wodenesse or in some agonye
I thoght how hit shuld be
Men shuld not knowe of goddes pⁱriuetye
Ȝei blissed be alwey the lewde mane .
That noȝt but onely his bylefe can
So ferde a nother clerk with his astronomye
He walked in to the feldes for to prye
Vppon the sterres to witte what shuld byfalle .
To he was in a marle pytte yfalle .
He saw not but ȝet by seint Thomas
Me rewith sore hende nycholas
He shall be ratyd of his studeyng
Ȝif þat I may by Ihus heuen kyng
Gete me a staffe that I may vnderspore .
While that þow Robyn hevist vp the dore
He shall oute of his studie as I gesse
And to the chambre dore he gan hym dresse
His knaue was a strong carle for the nones
And by the aspe he heft vp the dore at ones
In to the floure the dore felle a noone .
This nycholas satte ay stille as any stone
And euer gaped vpward in to the aiere .
This carpenter wende he were in despeire
And hent hym by the shuldres myghtely
And shoke hym herd and cried spytously
What nycholas what loke a doun
Awake and thenk on cristes passiou
I cruche the from euels ⁊and from wightes
Ther with the myght spell he seid anon rightes
On foure halfs of the hous aboute .
And on the thresfwold on the dore wᵗithoute .
Ihu crist and seint benedight
Blisse this hous from euery wikked wight
For the nyghtes . verie the white pater noster
Where wentestow . thow seynt petir suster
And at the laste this hende nycholas
Gan for to syke and seyd for love allas
Shall all the worlde be loste eft sones now
This carpenter ansuerd what seys þow
What thynk on god as we don men that swynke
This nycholas ansuerd feche me drynk
And after will I speke in pryuete
Of certen thyng that toucheth the ⁊and me
I will telle hit non other man certayn
This carpenter goth don and comyth agayn
And broght of myghty ale a large quart
And whan iche of hem had dronken his part
This nycholas his dore faste shette .
And don the carpenter by hym sette
And seist Iohn my hoste lefe ⁊and dere
Thow shalt vpon my trowth swere me here
That to no wight þow concell wreie .
For hit is cristes concele þat I seye
And ȝif þow telle hit man þow forlore .
For this vengeaunce þow shalt haue þ̉er/refore .
That ȝif þow wrie me þow shalt be woode
Nay crist forbede hit for his holy bloode .
Qd tho this sely man I nam no blabbe .
Ne thogh I sey hit I am lefe to gabbe
Sey what þow wolt I shall hit neủer/re telle .
To child ne wif by hym that harowed helle .
Now Iohn qd nycholas I will not lie .
I haue yfounden in myn astrologie
As I haue loked in the mone bryght
That now on moneday next a quart̉er/re nyght
Shalle falle a rayn ⁊and that so wild ⁊and woode
That half so grete was neủer/re noe floode .
This worlde shall he seid in lesse than an owre
Shall be dreynt so hidous is the showre .
Thus shall mankynd drenche and lose his lyf
This carpenter ansuerd alas my wif
And shall she drenche alas my Alison
For sorw of this he felle almost adone
And seid is ther any remedy in this caas
Why ȝus for god qd hende nycholas
Yf þow werchen after lore ⁊and rede .
Thow maist not wirchen after thyn owne hede .
For thus seith salamon that was full trewe .
Worke all by councell ⁊and than þow shalt not rewe .
And yf þow werken wolt by good councele .
I vndertake with outen maste or seile .
Ȝet shall I save her ⁊and the ⁊and me .
Hastow not herde . how saued was noe .
Whan that oure lord hath warned hym byforn
That al the worlde with water shuld be lorne
Ȝus qd the carpenter full yore ago .
Hastow not herd qd nycholas also
The sorow of noe with his felaschippe .
Or that he myght gete his wif to the shippe .
Hym had leuer I dar wele vndertake
At that thilk tyme than all wethers blake .
That she had a shippe hir self alone .
And therfore wostow what is be to done .
This axeth haste and of an hasty thynge .
Men may not preche . or maken taryeng
Anone go gete hus faste in to this Inne .
A knedyng troughe or ellys a kemelyn .
For eche of hus but loke that thei be large .
In whiche men may swym as in a barge .
And han her vitailes sufficiaunt
But for a day fy on the remenaunt
The water shall a slake and gon awey
Aboute pryme vppon the nexte day
But Robyn may noȝt wytte of this thy knaue .
Ne eke thi mayde gille I may not save
Axe not whi for þogh þow axe me .
I wille not tellen goddes priuete
Suffiseth the but ȝif thy wyttes madde
To haue as grete a grace as noe hadde
Thi wif shall I wele sauen out of doute
Go now thi wey and spede the here aboute .
But whan thow hast for her ⁊and the ⁊and me .
Ygeten vs thes knedyngs tuppes thre
Than shalt þow hang hem in rofe full hie
That no man of oure purueaunce aspie .
And whan þow thus hast done as I haue seide
And hast oure vitaile faire in hem y leyde .
And ete an axe to smyte the cordes a two .
Whan that the water comyth that we may go .
And broke an hoole on his vpon the gable .
Vn to the garden warde ouer the stable .
That we may frely passen forth oure wey
Whan that the grete shoure is gone awey
Than shalt þow swyme as mery I vndertake
As dothe the white doke after his drake
Than wole I clepe how Alison how Iohn
Be mery for the floode will passe anone
And þow wilt say haile maist̉er/re nicholay
Good morwe . I . see þe wele for hit is day
And than shall we be lordes alle our lyfe .
Of all the worlde as Noe and his wife
But that of o thyng I werne the full ryght
Be wele avised on that ilke nyght
That we bene entered in to the shippes borde
That none of vs speke noght aworde .
Ne clepe ne crie but bene in his pᵃiere .
For hit is goddes heste dere
Thy wif and þow mote hang ferre a twynne .
For that bytwyx ȝow shall be no synne .
Nomore in lokyng than ther shall in dede .
This ordinaunce is seid go god the spede .
To morwe . at nyght whan men ben all slepe
In to oure knedyng tubbes will we crepe .
And sitten there abydeng goddes grace .
Go now thy wey . I . haue no lenger space .
To make of this no lenger sermonyng
Men seyn thus send the wise . ⁊and sey no thing
Thow ert so wise hit nedeth the not to teche
God saue oure lyf and that I . the beseche
This sely carpenter goth forth his wey
Full oft he seyd alas and wele awey
And to his wyffe he tolde his priuete
And she was ware and knew it bett̉er/re than he .
What all queynte cast was for to sey
But natheles she ferde as she wolde deye .
And seid alas go forth thi wey anone
Helpe vs to scape or we ben dede ich one .
I am thi trwe verrey wedded wyf
Go dere spouse ⁊and help . to saue oure lyf
Loo what a grete thyng is affeccione .
Men may deie of ymaginacione
So depe may impressione be take
This sely carpenter begynneth to quake
Hym thynketh verraly that he may see .
Noe flood come walkyng as the see
To drenche alison his hony dere .
He wepith walith maketh sory chere .
He sigh with full mony a sory swogh
And goth and geteth hym a knedyng trogh
And after a tubbe and a kemelyne
And priuely he sent hem in to his In
And heng hem . in the roofe in priuete .
His owne hande he mayde laddres thre .
To clymben by the ronges . and the stalkes
Vn to the tubbes hangyng in the balkes
And hem vitailled both trogh and tubbe .
With brede ⁊and chese and goode ale in a Iubbe
Suffisyng ryght ynogh as for a day
But or that he had made all this array
He sent his knaue and eke his wenche also .
Vppon his nede to london for to go .
And on the monday whan hit droughe to nyght
He shette his dore with outen candell lyght
And dressed all thyng as hit shuld be
And shortely clomben vp all thre .
Thei sitten still wele a forlong way
Now pater noster clum seid nycholay
And clum qd Iohn and clum seid Alison
This carpenter seid his deuocion
And stille he sitte and byddith his pᵃiere .
Awaytyng on the rayn if he hit here .
The detth slepe for verrey besynesse .
Fill on this carpenter ryght as I gesse
Aboute couerfwe . tyme or lytell more .
For trayuale of his gost he groneth sore .
And efte he routeth for his hede myslay
Done of the ladder stalketh nycholay
And Alson full sone . a doun she spedde .
With outen wordes mo . thei go to bedde .
There as the carpenter is wont to lye .
There was the revell and the melodie
And thus lith Alison and Nicholas
In besynesse of merthe and of solas
Tylle that belle of laudes gan to rynge .
And freres in the chauncell gonne to syng
This paryssh clerk this amerous Absolon .
That is for love alwey for woo begone
Vppon the monday was at Osney
With company hym to disport and pley
And axed vppon caas a cloistrer
Full priuely after Iohn carpenter
And he drough hym a part oute of the chirch
And seid I not I saugh hym here noȝt werche
Sithe saturday I trowe that he be went
For tymber there oure Abbot hath hym sent
For he is wont for tymbre for to go .
And dwellen at grange a day or two .
Or elles he is at his hous certeyn .
Where that he bene I can not sothely seyn .
This absolon full Ioly was and lyght
And thoght now is tyme to wake all nyght
For sekirly . I . saugh hym noȝt styring
Abouten his dore syn day began to spryng
So mote I thryfe . I shall at cokkes crowe .
Full priuely knokken at his wyndowe .
That stonde full lowe apon his bowres walle .
To Alison now wille I tellen alle
My loue longyng for ȝet I shall not mysse .
That at the last wey I shall her kysse .
Som maner comforte shall I haue ꝑper/par ma fay
My mouthe . hath yched all this long day
That is a signe of kyssing atte leeste
All nyght me met eke I was at a fest
Therfore I wolde go slepe an owre or tweie .
And all the nyght than will I wake ⁊and pley
Whan that the first cokke hath crowe anoone .
Vp ryse this ioly louer absolone .
And hym arraith gay and a poynt deuyse
But ferst he chewith grayn and licoryse
To smellen sote or he had kempt his here
Vnder his tonge a trew loue he bere
For therby wende he to be gracious
He rometh to the carpenter hous
And still he . stonde vnder the shot wyndowe .
Vn to his brest hit raught hit was so lowe .
And soft he coughed with a semy sown .
What doth hony comb . swete Alison .
My faire bryd my swete synamome .
Awaketh lēmman and speke to me .
Wele litell thynketh ȝe vppon my woo .
That for youre loue . y . swete as y go .
No wonder is þogh that . I . swelt and swete .
I morne as doth the lambe after the tete
Ywisse lēmman . I . haue such loue longyng
That ilke a turtell trewe is my mornyng
I may ete no more than a mayde .
Go fro the wyndow Iakke foole she seyde .
As help me god . hit will not be come ba me .
I loue an other and elles I were to blame
Wele bette than the by seint Iohn absolon
Go forth thi wey or y will cast a ston
And lete me slepe a twenty deuel wey
Alas qd absolon and wele awey
That trewe loue was euer so euell bysette .
Than kisse me syn hit may be no bette
For Ihıı̄uns loue and for the love of me
Wole thow than go thi wey ther with qd she .
Ȝei certes lēmman qd this absolon .
Than make the redy qd she I come anone .
This absolon done sette hym on his knees
And seid I am a lorde at all degrees
For after this ther cōmmith more .
Lēmman thi grace . and swete brid thyn ore .
The wyndow she vndoth and that in hast
Haue do qd she come of and spede the fast
Lest that oure neighboures the aspie .
This absolon gan wipe his mouthe ful drie .
Derk was the nyght as piche or as the cole .
And at the wyndow out she put her hole
And absolon hym fell no bette ne wars
But with his mouthe he kissed her naked ars
Full sauerly or he were ware of this .
A bake he stert and thoght hit was amysse
Full wele he wist a wōmman had no berde .
He fellyd a thyng all rough ⁊and longe yhered .
And seid . alas what haue y don
Te he qd she and clapt the wyndow to .
And Absolon goth forth a sory pas
A berde a berde seid hend nycholas
By goddes corpus this goth faire ⁊and wele .
This sely absolon herde hit euerydele .
And on his lyppe he gan for angur byte
And to hym self he seid I shall the quyte .
Who rubbeth now . who fretyth now his lyppes
With duste with sonde with strawe wᵗith cloth wᵗith chippes
But absolon that seith full ofte alas
My soule I betake to sathanas
But me were leuer than all this toune qd he
Of this dispite awroken for to be .
Alas qd he alas . I ne hadde ybleynt
His hote loue is colde and all yqueynt
For fro that tyme that he had kist her ers
Of ꝑper/paramorus he sette not a kresse .
For he was helyd of his malodie
Full ofte ꝑper/paramorus he kan diffye
And wept as doth a child that is ybette
A soft paas he went ouer the strete
Vn till a smyth men clepen dan Gervays
That in his forge smyteth plogh harnays
He sharpith shaare and culter besyly
This Absolon knokketh all esyly
And seid to geruais vppon and that anone .
What art þow hit am I absolon .
What absolon what cristes swete tree .
Why ryse ȝe so rath ey benedicite
What eileth ȝow som gay grille god hit wote
Hath brouȝt ȝow thus on the viritoote
By seint notte ȝe wote wele what I mene
This absolon ne rought not a bene
Of all his pley no word agayn he gaffe
He had more tawe on his dystaffe
Than geruays knew and seid frend so dere
The hote culter in the chemenye here
As lene hit me I haue ther with to done .
I will bryng hit agayne full sone .
Geruais ansuerd certys were hit golde .
Or in a poke nobles all vn tolde .
Thow shuldes haue as I am trew Smyth
Ey cristes foot what will ȝe do ther with
Ther of be as qd Absolon be may
Y shall wele tellen hit the to morwe at day
And caught the culter by the colde stele
Full soft out at the dore he can stele
And went vn to the carpent̉er/re wall
He coughed fyrst and knokked ther wᵗith alle
Vppon the wyndow ryght as he did ere .
This Alison answerd who is there .
That knokketh so I warant hit a thefe .
Why nay qd he god wote my swete lefe
I am thyn absolon . thy derlyng
Of gold qd he I haue broght the ryng
My moder ȝaf hit me so god me save .
Full fyne hit is and þer to wele ygraue .
This wole I ȝif the ȝif þow me kysse .
This nycholas was rysen . for to pysse .
And thought ho wolde amenden . all the Iape .
He shuld kysse hys ers or that he scape .
And vp the wyndow did he hastily
And out his ers he putte pryuely
Ouer the buttok to the hanche bone
And ther with spake this clerk this absolon .
Speke swote bryd I not where thow ert
This nycholas lete flye a fert
As grete as hit as hit hadde ben a thonder dent
That with the stroke he was almost yblent
And he was redy with the yren hoot
And nycholas in the ers he smote
Of goth the skyn an handbrede aboute
The hoote culter brenned so his toute .
That for hit smerte he went for to dye .
As he were wode for woo . he can to crye .
Help water water helpe for goddes hert
This carpenter oute of his slomber stert
And herd one crye water as he were woode
And thoght alas now cōmmeth noe floode
And sette hym vp with oute wordes mo
And with an axe . he smote the corde atwo .
And done goth all he fonde neither to selle .
Ne brede ne ale tylle he come to the felle .
Vppon the floure . and ther a swone he lay
Vp sterte hir alison . and nycholay
And cried out harow in the strete
The neighbours both smale ⁊and grete .
Y ronnen for to gauren . on this man .
That a swone lay both pale ⁊and wan
For with that falle he brosten hath his arme
But stonden he most vn to his owne harme
For whan he spake he was anon borne . done .
With hend nycholas and Alison .
Thei tolde euery man that he was wode
He was agast so of Noes floode .
Thurgh fantasie that of his vanyte .
He hadde . yboght hym knedyng tubbes thre .
And had hem hanged in the roof aboue .
And that he prayd hem for goddes loue
To setten in the roof ꝑper/par company
This folk gan laughen at his fantasy
And to the roof thei kiken and thei gape .
And turned hym harme vn to a Iape
For what so this carpenter ansuerde
Hit was for noght no man his reson herde .
With othes grete he was so sworne a done
That he was holden wode in all the toune
For euery clerk a noone ryȝt held with other
Thei seid the man is wood my lefe brother
And euery wight gan laghen at his stryfe .
Thus chaped the carpenters wyfe
For all his kepyng and his ielousie
And absolon hath kyst her nether eye
And nycholas is scalded in the toute
This tale is done and god saue all the route

(base) And sodeynly he loued this kyte so
