div.l: IN feith squier þᵘ hast the wele yquytte
And gentilly . I prayse wele thi wytte .
Qd the merchaunte . consideryng thy ȝouthe .
So felyngly thow spekest sir I the allouthe
As to my dome there is non that is here .
Of eloquence that shall be thy pere .
For of thy speche I haue grete deynte
I haue a sone and by the trinite
I hadde leuer þan xxᵗⁱ pond worth of lond
Þogh hit right now were fallen in my hond .
He were a man of suche discrecion
As þat ȝe ben . fy vppon possession .
But ȝif a man be vertuos with alle .
I haue my sone snobbed ⁊and ȝet shalle .
For he to vertu lyst not entende .
But for to pley at dies . and to dispende .
And lese alle that he hath . is his vsage .
And he hath leuer with a page
Talke . than cōmmune wᵗith any gentill wight
Where he might lerne gentilnesse aright .
Straw for youre gentilnesse qd oure ooste .
What merchant ꝑper/parde . wele þou woste .
That eche of yow mote tellen at the leste
A tale or two or breken his biheste .
That knowe I wele qd the merchant c̉er/reteyn .
I pᵃy ȝow not haue me in desdeyn
Thogh to this man I speke a worde or two .
Telle on thi tale wᵗith oute wordes moo .
Gladly ʆser/sir ooste qdhe I will obeye
Vn to ȝoure wille . now herkeneth what I sey
I will not ȝoᵘur contᵃrie in no wise .
As ferre as that my / wittes wille suffice .
I pᵃy to god . that hit may plesen yow .
Than wote I wele that it is good ynow
Than wote I wele that it is goode ynow .
Whylom ther was dwellyng in lombardy
A worthy knyght that born was at pavy
In whiche he leued in grete ꝓprosperite
And sixty ȝere a wifles man was he
And folowed ay his bodily delite
On wōmman ther as was his appetite
As done thes foules that ben seculers
And whan that he was passed sixty ȝeres
Were hit for holynesse or elles for dotage
I can not sey but such a grete corage
Hadde this grete knyght to be awedded man
That day ⁊and nyght he doth alle that he can
To aspie where that he wedded myght be
Praynge oure lord to gᵃunten hym that he
Mighte ones knowe þat blisful lyfe
That is betwyx an housbond ⁊and an wyfe
And for to leuyir vnder that holy bonde
With which god syft man to wōmman bande
None other lyfe seid he is worth a bene
For wedloke is so hesy and so clene
That in this worlde hit is a ꝑper/paradyse
Thus seid this olde knyght that was so wyse
And certenly as soth as god is kyng
To take a wyf hit is a glorious thing
And namely whan a man is olde ⁊and hore
Then is a wyfe þe fruyte of his tresore
Than shuld he take a yong wyf and a feyre
On whiche he might engendre hym an eyre
And leyd his lyf in ioy and in solace
Whan as the bachelers seyn allas
Whan thei fynde any aduersite
In loue whiche that is but childes vanyte
And trewly hit sitte wele to be soo
That bachelers han ofte peyn ⁊and woo
On brutel grounde thei belde brutelnesse
Thei fynde when thei . wene sekernesse
Thei lyue but abryd or a beste
In liberte and vnder nyce areste
There as aweddyd man in his astate
Lyueth his lyue blysful and ordinate
Vnder the yok of mariage ybounde
Wele may his herte in ioy ⁊and blisse be bounde
For who can be so buxume as a wyfe
Who is so trewe and eke so tentyfe
To kepe hym sike and hole as is his make
For wele ne who she nyl hym not forsake
She is not wery hym to love ⁊and serve
Þogh that he ley beddered til he sterve
And ȝet some clerkes seyn that it is noȝt so
Of whiche Theofraste is one of tho
What forse þogh Theofraste lyste to lye
Ne take no wyf qd he for housbondrye
As for to spare in houshold thi despence
A trwe seruaunt doth more diligence
Thi goode to kepe than thyn owne wyfe
For she wole cleyme half parte al hir lyfe
And ȝif that þou be sike so god me save
Thi verray frendes or a trewe knaue
Wole kepe the better þan she þᵗat waytheth ay
After thi goode ⁊and hath don mony a day
And ȝif þow take a wyf that to the is vntrewe
Ful ofte tyme hit shal the rewe
This entent ⁊and an hundred sithes wors
Writeth this man ther god his bones curse
But take no kepe of al such vanite ıı̄un
Defie Theofrast and herkeneth me
A wyfe is goddes ȝift verraly
Al other many ȝiftes hardely
As landes rentes pasturs or cōmmune
Or mebles al ben ȝiftes of fortune
That passen as a shadowe on a wal
But drede hit noȝt pleynly speke shal I
A wyf wil last ⁊and in thyn hous endure
While that thow . lust ꝑper/parauenture
Mariage is a ful grete sacᵃment
The which hath no wyf I telle hym shent
He lyves helples and is all desolate
I speke of folke in seculer estate
And herkeneth why I sey not this for noȝt
The wōmman is for māmnes help ywroȝt
The hie god whan he hadde adam maked
And see hym allone by naked
God of his grete goodnes seid than
Lete vs make an help to this man
Lyke to hym self and þan he made Eue
Here may ȝe se and her by many a preve
That wyfes is māmnes comforte
His ꝑper/paradys terrestre and his disporte
So buxoun and so vertuos is she
Thei moste nedes lyve in vnite
Oo flessh thei ben and two soules I gesse
Hath but one hert in hele ⁊and in destresse
A wyf a seint . marie benedicite
How might a man haue any aduersite
That hath a wyf certes I can not sey
The blysse that is betuyx hem twey
Ther may no tonge tellen ne hert thynke
Yf he be pore she helpeth hym to swynke
She kepeth his goode and wasteth hit neủer/re a dele
Alle that hir housbond lust hir lyketh wele
She seith not ones nay whan he seith ȝer
Do thus seith he al redy sir seith she
O blisful ordre of wedlok precious
Thow art so mery and so eke vertuous
And so cōmmendid and so . appued eke
That euery man that hold hym worthy a leke
Vpon his bare knees aught al his lyf
Thankyn his god that hym hath send a wyf
Other prey to god hym for to sende
A wyfe to laste vn to his lyves ende
For then his lyf is sette in sikernesse
He may not be disseyued as I gesse
So that he werche after his wyfes rede
Then may he boldely bere vp his hede
Thei be so trewe and so wys
For which ȝif þou wilt worchen as þe wise
Do al wey so as wōmmen . wil the rede
Loo how that Iacob . as the clerkes rede
By goode councele of his moder Rebekke
Bounde the kyd skynnes aboute his nekke
For which his fader benysou he wan
Loo Iudith as the story telle can
By wyse councele she goddis peple kepte
And slow hym Olefernes whilest he slepte
Loo Abigael by goode councele how she
Saued hir housbound Nabal whan that he
Shuld haue ben slayne and loke after also
By goode councele Ester delyuerdout of woo
The peple of god and made hym MarcheMardocheMardoche
Of assuere enhauncyd for to be ıı̄un
Ther nys no thyng in gree suꝑper/parlatyf
As seith senek aboue an humble wyf
Suffre thi wyfes tounge as catou byd
She shul comaunde and þᵘ shal suffre hit
And ȝit she wole obeie of curtesie
A wyf is keꝑper/par of thyn housbondrie
Wele may the sike man be waile ⁊and wepe
Ther as nys no wyfe his hous to kepe
I werne the ȝif þow wisely thow wirche
Loue wele thi wyfe as crist loueth his chirch
Ȝif þow louest thi self wele þᵘ louest thi wyfe
No man hateth his flessh but in his lyfe
He forsterith hit and þerfore byd I the
Cherissh thi wyf or thow shalt neuer ythe
Housbond and wyfe what so men Iape or pley
Of wordely folk haue thei the seker wey
Thei be so knyt ther may no harme betide
And namely vppon the wyfes side
For which this Ianuarie of which I tolde
Considered hath in which his daies olde
The lusty lyf the vertuouos quiete
That is in mariage hony swete
And for his frendes on a day he sent
To tellen hem the effecte of his entent
With face sadde this tale he hath hem tolde
He seid frendes I am hore ⁊and holde
And almost god wote on my pittes brynke
Vpon my soule somwhat most I thinke
I haue my body folily dispended
Blissed be god that I shal be amended
For I wole bene certeyn a wedded man
And that anone in alle the hast I kan
Vnto some mayde faire and tendre of age
I pᵃy shape for my mariage
Al sodenly for I wil not abide
And I wole founden to aspie on my side
To whom I may be weddyd hastily
But for as moche as ȝe ben moo than I left
Ȝe shullen rather such a thing aspien
Then I and ther me lust best to alien
But oo thing warne I the my frendes dere
I wole non olde wyf haue in no manere
She shal not passen xvj . ȝere certen
Olde fissh ⁊and yong flessh that wold I haue haue c̉er/reten
Bet is qd he a pyke than a Pikerel
And bet than olde beef is the tendre veel
I wil no wōmman of thretty wynt̉er/re age
Hit is but bene strawe ⁊and grete forage
And eke this oldes wyfes god hit wote
So mochel broke harme can whan hem lest
That with hem shuld I haue neuer rest
For sundry scoles makes subtil clerkes
Wōmman of many scoles half a clerk is
But c̉er/retenly a yong thing may a man gie
Right as men may warme wex wᵗith handes plye
Wherfore I sey ȝow pleynly in a clause
I wil non olde wife haue right for this caus
For ȝif so were I had some meschaunce
That in hir ne couth I haue no plesaunce
Than shuld I lede my lyf in auenture
And so strette to the deuel sure
Ne children shuld I none vp on hir geten
That had I leuer þᵗat hondes had me eten
Then that my heritage shuld falle
In straunge hande ⁊and thus I telle yow alle
I doute noght I note noght þe cause why ıı̄un
Men shulde wedde ⁊and forthermore wote I
Ther speketh mony a man of mariage
That wote nomore of hit than doth my page
For which causes men shuld take a wyf
Ȝif he may be not chaste be his lyfe
Take hym a wyf with grete deuocione
Bicause of lawful ꝑper/parcreacione
Of children to the honour of god aboue
And noȝt onely for ꝑper/paramoure ne for loue
And for the shulden lechery eschewe
And ȝelde hir dettes while that it is newe
Or for that ech man shulde helpen other
In meschef as a suster shuld a brother
And lyue in chastite ful heuenly
But sirs by youre leve þat am not I
For god bithanke it I dar make avaunte
I fele my lymes starke ⁊and insufficesaunte
To done al that a man bilongeth to do
I wote my selfe best what I may do
Þogh I be hore I fare as doth a tree
That blosometh or þᵗat fruyt I wox be
That blossomed tre is nother drie ne dede
I fele nawhere hore but on my hede
Myn herte and my lymes bene as grene
As lawrel is thorugh the ȝere for to sene
And sithyns ȝe haue herd al myn entent
I pᵃy ȝow to my wil ȝe assent
Diuerse men diủer/resely hym tolde
Of mariage mony ensamples olde
Some blameth it some preyseth it c̉er/retayne
But at the last shortely for to sayne
As alday falleth alt̉er/recacione
Bytwyx frendes in disputacione
Ther felle a stryf betwyx his bretheryn two
Of whiche that one was clepid Placebo
Iustinus sothely called was that other
Placebo seid so I am youre brother
Ful litel nede haue ȝe my lorde so dere
Councele to aske of any that is here
But that ȝe ben so ful of sapience
That ȝow ne liketh for youre hie prudence
To wayue fro the word of salamon
This worde seith he vn to vs euerychon
Werke al thing by councele thus seid he
And than shal youre no repente the
But þogh that salamōmn speke such a worde
Myn owne dere brother and my lorde
So wyssely god bryng my soule at ese ⁊and reste
I holde ȝoure owne councele is the beste
For brother take of me this motyf
I haue ben now a courte man al my lyfe
And god wote þogh I vnworthy be
I haue stonden in ful grete degree
Aboue lordes in ful grete astate
Ȝit had neủer/re with non of hem debate
I neủer/re hem contraried trewly
I wote wele þat my lorde can more þan I
That he seith I holde hit ferme ⁊and stable
I sey the same or ellys thyng semblable
A ful grete foole is any counceloure
That seruyth any lorde of hie honoure
That dar presume or onys thynk hit
That his councele shal passe his lordes wytte
Nay lordes be no fooles by my fay
Ȝe haue ȝoure selfe here spoken to day
So hie sentence so holy and wele
That I consente and conferme euery dele
Ȝoure wordes alle and youre opynyone
By god ther is no man in al this toune
Ne in Itale coude better han seide
Crist holdeth hym of this ful wele a payed
And trewly it is an hie corage
Of eny man that stopyng is in age
To take a yong wyf by my fader kyn
Youre hert hangeth vppon a Ioly pyn
Doth now in this mater right as ȝow leste
For finally I holde hit for þe beste
Iustinus that ay stille satte ⁊and herde
Right in this wyse he to placebo ansuerde
Now brother myn be pacient I pᵃy
Sithyns that ȝe haue seid herkene what I sey
Seneke amonges other wordes wyse
Seith that a man oghte hym wele avyse
To whome he ȝeveth his lande or his catel
And sithyns I aughte avise me riȝt wele
To whome I ȝeue my body for alwey
I werne ȝow wele it is no childes pley
To taken a wif with outen avisament
Men most enquere this is myn assent
Whethir she be wyse sobre or dronkelewe
Other proude or other wyse a shrewe
A chydester other a waster of thy goode
Other riche or pore or ellis a man is wode
Al be it so that no man fynden shulle
None in this worlde that trotteth hole in alle
Ne man ne best such as men can devise
But natheles it aught ynogh suffice
With any wyf ȝif so were that she hadde
Moo goode thewes than hir vices badde
And alle asketh layser to enquere
For god wote I haue wept many a tere
For prevely sithens I hadde a wyfe
Preyse who so wole a wedded māmnys lyfe
Certeyn I fynde in hit but coste ⁊and care
And obseruaunces of alle blisses bare
And ȝet god thank my neighbours aboute
And namely of wōmmen a gret rowte
Sayne that I haue the most stedfast wyfe
And eke the mekest oone that bereth lyfe
But I wote beste where wryngeth my sho
Ȝe most for me right as ȝow lust do
Aviseth ȝow ȝe ben a man of age
How that entren in to mariage
And namely with a yong wyf ⁊and a feyre
By hym that made water erth and eyre
The yongest man that is in alle the route
Is besy ynogh to bryngen hit aboute
To haue his wyf allone trusteth me
Ȝe shulle not plesen hir ȝeres thre
This is to seyn to done hir plesaunce
A wyfe axeth ful mony obseruaunce
I pᵃy ȝow that ȝe be euyl apayed
Wele qd this Ianuarie ⁊and hast þou al ysayed
Strawe for thi seneke and for thy ꝓprouerbes
I counte not a panȝer ful of herbes
Of scole termes wyser men than thow
As þou hast herd assentith hit right nowe
To my purpos placebo what sey ȝe
I seid hit is a cursed man qd he
That letteth matrimone sikerly
And with that worde thei risen sodenly
And ben assented fully that he shulde
Bene wedded when hym luste ⁊and wher he wold
Thyn fantasie and thyn curiousnesse
Fro day to day gan in thy soule impresse
Of Ianuarie aboute his mariage
Many fair shappe and many a fair visage
There passeth his herte nyght by nyght
As who so so toke a myrrour polysshed brighte
And sette hit in a cōmmune marketh place
Than shuld he seyn mony a figure pace
By his myrrour and in the same wyse
Gan Ianuarie inwith his thogh devyse
Of maydens which that duellith besyde
He wiste not where that he might abyde
For þoght that oone had beaute in hir face
A nother stont as in the peples gᵃce
Forhi sadenesse and benignite
That of the peple grettest vois hadde she
And some were riche and hadden badde name
But natheles betwyx ernest and game
He at the last enpoynted hym in sone
And lete all other from his herte gone
And chese hir of his owne autorite
For loue is blynd alday ⁊and may not see
And whan that he was in the bedde ybrought
He portreyd in his herte and in his thoght
Hir fressh beaute ⁊and hir age tendre
Hir myddel smale hir armes long ⁊and slender
Hir wyse goủer/renaunce and hir gentilnesse
Hir wōmman bering and hir gentil sadenesse
And whan that he was condescended
Hym thoght his chois might not ben amended
For when that he hym selfe concluded hadde
Hym thoght ilke other manes witte so badde
That impossible it were to replie
Aȝein his chois this was his fantasie
His frendes sent he to at his instance
And peth hem to done hym that plesaunce
That hastely thei wolde to hym come
He wolde abbreggen her labour al ⁊and some
Hit nedith nomore to gone or ride
He was apoynted ther he wolde abide
Placebo come and eke his frendes sone
And alder first he bade hem a bone
That none of hem none argumenteȝ make
Aȝeins his purpos which that he hath ytake
Whiche purpos was plesaunt to god as seid he
And verray grounde of his ꝓprosperite
He seide ther was a maiden in the towne
Whiche that of beaute hath grete renoun
Alle were hit she were of smale degree
Suffiseth hym hir ȝouth and hir beaute
Whiche maide he seid he wolde hir haue to wyf
To leden in ease and in holynesse his lyfe
And thanketh god that he myght hir alle
That no wight his blysse parte shalle
And preieth hym to laboure in this nede
And shapeth that he fayleth noght to spede
For than he seid his spirit was at ease
Then is qd he no thing þᵗat may me displese
Safe on thing priketh in my conscience
The wheche I wil reherse in youre psence
I haue qd he herd sey ful ȝere ago . ıı̄un
There may no man haue ꝑper/parfite blisses twoo
This is to sey in erthe and eke in heuene
For þogh he kepe hym frome the synnes seuene
And eke from euery braunche of thilke tree
Ȝet is there so ꝑper/parfite ꝓprosꝑper/parite
And so grete eese and luste in mariage
That euer I am agast nowe so mery a lyf here
For sithyns that verrey heuen is boght so der
With tribulacion and grete penaunce
How I shuld lyve in suche plesaunce
As alle wedded men doth with hir wyfes
Come to the blysse ther crist eterne on lyve is
This is my drede and ȝe my bretheren tweye
Assoileth me this question y yow preye
Iustinus with that hated his folie
Ansuerde anone right in his Iaperie
And for he wolde his long tale abregge
He wolde non autorite for hym alege
But seid sir so þer be non obstacle
Other than god of his hie myracle
And of his mercy may so for yow werche
That ar ȝe haue youre ȝiftes of holy chirche
Ȝe may repente of wedded māmnys lyve
In whiche ȝe seyne ther nys nethir woo ne stryve
And ellys god forbede but he sente
A wedded man grace to repente
Wele often rather than a sengle man
And therfore sir the best redde I can
Desperith ȝow noght haueth in memorie
Pauenture she may be youre purgatorie
She may be goddes mene and goddis whippe

And Ianuarie and Mayus rownyng ful mery
Briȝt was the day ⁊and blew the firmament
Phebus of gold doun hath his stremes sent
To gladen eủer/rey floure with his warmnesse
He was that in Gemini as I gesse
But litel from his declinacion
Of Canser Iouis exaltacion
And so bifel that in a bright morwtyde
That in that Gardyn on that firther syde
Pluto that is the kyng of faireye
And many a lady in his cumpany
Folowyng his wyffe the quene ꝓproserpina
Which that he rauysshed oute of ꝓproserpina
Whilest that she gadred floures in a mede
In claudian ȝe may the stories rede
How in his grisely cart he hir sette
This kyng of faireye doun hym sette
Vpon a benche of torves fressh ⁊and grene
And right anone seid he thus to his quene
My wyf qd he that may noȝt say nay
The exꝑper/parience provith hit eủer/rey day
The tresoun which that wōmmen doth to man
Ten hundred thousand telle I can
Notable of youre vntrouth ⁊and britilnesse
O salamon richest of al richesse
Fulfilled with sapiens and of worldly glorie
Ful worthy bene thi wordes to memorie
To eủer/rey wight that witte ⁊and reson kan
Thus preisith he ȝit the bounte of man
Among a thousand ȝit fonde I one
But of al wymen fonde he neủer/re none
Thus seith this kyng that knew youre wikkednesse
And Ihus filius cirak as I gesse
Ne speketh of yow but seldyn reủer/reence
A wilde fire a corupte pestilence
So falle vpon youre bodies ȝit to nyȝte
Ne see ȝe noȝt this honorable knyȝt
Bicaus alas that he is blynd ⁊and olde
His owne man shal make hym cokewolde
Loo where he sitte the lechoure in the tree
Now wyl I gᵃunte of my mageste
Vn to this olde blynd worthy knyȝte
That he shal haue aȝen his eyen sight
Whan that his wyfe wolde done hym vilenye
Than shal he knawe al hir harlotrie
Both in reprofe of hir and othir moo
Ȝei shal qd ꝓproserpina and wole ȝe soo
Now by my moders sires soule I swere
That I shal ȝiffen hir sufficeaunt ansuere
And al wymen after for youre sake
That ȝif thei bene in any gilt ytake
With face bolde thei shullen hem self excuse
And bere hem doun that wolde hem accuse
For lakke of ansuere none of hem shullen deyen
Al had ȝe seyn a thing with both youre eyen
Ȝit shullen we so visage hit hardily
And wepe ⁊and swere ⁊and chide subtily
That ȝe shullen bene as lewde as ar gees
What rekketh me of youre auctorites
I wote wele this Iewe this Salamon
Fond of vs wōmmen folys mony oone
But þogh that he fond no good wōmman
Ther hath yfonde mony an oþ̉er/re man
Wōmmen ful trewe ful good vertuous
Wyttenesse of hem that duellyn in cⁱstes hous
With martirdome þei provid hem constance
The Romane gestes maken remembraunce
Of many a trewe wyfe also
But ʆser/sir be noȝt wrothe as be hit so
Þogh that he seid he fond no good wōmman
I pᵃy ȝow take the sentence of þe man
He mente thus that in soủer/reaigne bounde
Nys none but god but neither be necessite
Ey for verrey god that nys but one
What make ȝe so moche of Salamon
What þogh he made a temple goddis hous
What þogh he were riche and glorious
So made he a temple of fals goddis
Who myȝt do a thyng that more for bode is
ꝐPer/Parde as fair as ȝe his name in plastre
He was a lechoure and an ydolastre
And in his elde he verrey god forsoke
And ȝif that god ne had as seith the book
Ysparyd hym for his faders sake he sholde
Haue loste his reigne souner than he wolde
I sette noȝt of al the vilanye
That ȝe of wōmmen write a butterflie
I am a wōmman nedys most I speke
Or ellis swelle til my hert breke
For syn he seid that we bene Iangelers
As euer mote I broke both my tresses
I shul not spare for no curtesie
To speke hym harme that wole vs vilanye
Dame qd this pluto be no lenger wrothe
I ȝif hit vp but syn I swore myn othe
That I wolde graunten hym his siȝte aȝayne
My worde shal stande that warne I the certayne
I am a kyng hit sitte me noȝt to lye
And I qd she a queene of faireye
Hir ansuere she shal haue I vndertake
Lete vs nomore wordes make
For soth I wole no lenger ȝow contᵃrie
Now lete vs turne aȝayn to Ianuarie
That in this gardyn with this fair may
Syngeth full meryer than the popen Iay
Ȝow loue I best and shul and oþ̉er/re none
So longe aboute the Ales is he gone
Til he come agaynes thilk pirie
Where as this damyan sitteth ful merye
Onhighe amonge þe fressh leves grene
This fressh may that is so bright ⁊and shene
Gan for to sike and sayd alas my syde
Now ʆser/sir qd she for oght that may be tyde
I moste haue of the peres that I see
Or I mote deye for sore longeth me
To eten of the smale peres grene
Helpe for hir loue that is of heuen quene
I telle ȝoᵘ wele a wōmman in my plite
May haue to some fruyt so grete an appetite
That she may deien but she it haue
Allas qd he that I ne had here a knaue
That couth clymbe allas allas qd he
For I am blynde ȝe ʆser/sir no fors qd she
But wolde ȝe voche saue for goddes sake
The piry in with youre armes for to take
For wele I wote that ȝe mystruste me
Than shulde I clymbe wele ynogh qd she
Soo I my foote myght sette vppon youre bake
For soth seid he in me shal be no lake
Might I ȝoᵘ help wᵗith my hert bloode
He stoupeth doun and on his bakke she stoode
And caught hir by a twyst and vp she goth
Ladyes I pᵃy ȝow be not wrothe
I can noght glose I am a rude man
And sodanly anon this Damyan
Gan pullen vp the smoke ⁊and he in he throng
And whan that pluto saugh this grete wrong
To Ianuarie he ȝaf his sight agayn
Ne was ther neuer man of thing so fayn
But on his wyffe his thoght was eủer/remoo
Vp to the tre he kest his eyen two
And see that Damyan his wyffe had dressed
In whiche man it may not bene expssed
But ȝif I wolde speke vncurtesly
And vp he ȝaffe a roryng and a cry
As doth the moder whan the child shal deye
Oute help alas harow he gan to crie
O strong lady stoure what dotth thow
And she ansuerid ʆser/sir what eilith ȝow
Haue pacience and reson in ȝoure mynde
I haue ȝow holpen on bothe youre eyen blynde
Vp ꝑper/paril of my soule I shal not lien
As me was taught to hele with youre n
Was no thing bett̉er/re for to make ȝow see
Than strogle with a man vpon a tree
God wote I dede it in ful goode entent
Strogle qd he ȝei algate in hit went
God ȝif yow both on shames deth to deien
He swyued the I saugh hit wᵗith myn eyen
And elles be I hanged by the hals
Than is qd she the medicyne fals
For certanly if þat ȝe myghten see
Ȝe wolde not say þo wordes to me
Ȝe haue some glymsyng ⁊and no ꝑper/parfite sight
I see qd he as wele as euer I myght
Thanked be god with both myn eyen two
And by my trouth me thoght he did the soo
Ȝe mase mase goode sir qd she
This thank haue I for I haue made ȝoᵘ see
Alas qd she þᵗat eủer/re I was so kynde
Now dame qd he let al passe out of mynde
Come doun my leef ⁊and ȝif I haue myssaide
God help me so as I am euel a paide
But by my fader soule I wende haue seyn
How that this Damyan had by the leyn
And that thi smoke had lyen vpon thi brest
Ȝei ʆser/sir qd she ȝe may wene as yow lest
But ʆser/sir a man þᵗat waketh oute of his slepe
He may not sodanly wele take kepe
Vpon a thing ne seen it ꝑper/parfitely
Til that he be adawed verrely
Right so a man that longe hath blynd be
Ne may not sodanly so wele y see
First whan the sight is newe cōmmyn agayn
As he that hath a day or two I sayn
Til that youre sight ystabled be awhile
Ther may ful many a sight yow begile
Beith ware I pᵃy ȝow for by heuen kyng
Ful many a man wenyth for to see a þing
And hit is al other than it semeth
He that mys conceyueth mysdemyth
And with that worde she lepe doun fro þe tree
This Ianuarie who is glad but he
He kisseth her ⁊and clippeth her ful ofte
And on hir wombe he stroketh hir ful softe
And to his Paleis home he hath hir ladde
Now good men I pᵃy ȝow to be gladde
Thus endith here my tale of Ianuarie
God blisse vs and his moder seint marie
Oure oost gan tho to loke vp anone .
Goode men qd he . herkeneth eủer/reychou
As eủer/re mote I drinke wyne or ale .
This merchaunt hath ytolde a mery tale
How Ianuarie . hadde a lither Iape .
His wiffe put in his hoode an . ape .
But here of will I love of as . now
Dame wyfe of bath qd he I þᵘy ȝow
Telle vs a tale now next after this
Sir oost qd she . so god my soule blisse
As I fully þ̉er/reto will consente .
And also it is myn hole entente
To done ȝow all disporte . as þᵗat I kan
But holde me excusid I am a woman
I can not reherse as these clerkis kune /
div.fw: The wyffe of Baathes tale/ or prologe .
div.l: And right anone she hath hir tale byginne .
And right anone she hath hir tale bygune .
Exꝑper/parience . thogh noone auctorite .
Were in this worlde . is right ynogh for me .
To speke of woo . that is in mariage .
For lordinges syn I . twelue . ȝeer had of age .
Thanked be god that is eterne alyve .
Housbondes at the chirch dore I haue hadde fyve .
Ȝif I so ofte myght haue weddid be .
And al wer worthy men in hir degre
But me was tolde . certan . not long agon is
That crist went neủer/re but ones
To weddyng in the cane . of galilee
That by the same ensample . he taght me .
That I ne shuld wedded be but onys
Herken eke . what a sharpe . worde for þe nonys
Bysydes a welle Ihs god and man
Spake in reprofe . to þe Samaritan
Þoᵘ hast yhad fyve . housbondes . qd he .
And that thilke man that now . hath the .
Is not thyn . housbond thus seid he certayn .
But that I axe . why the fifte man
Was noȝt housbond to the samaritan
How mony myȝt she haue in mariage .
Ȝet herde I . neủer/re tellen . in my age .
Vppon this nombr . diffinicion
Men may deuyne . ⁊and glosen vp ⁊and doun
But wele I wote . expsse . with outen lye .
God bad vs to wexen ⁊and multiplie .
That gentil texte . can I wele . vnderstonde
Wele I wote that myn housbonde .
Shulle lefe fader ⁊and moder ⁊and take me .
But of no nombre mencion made he .
Of bigamie or of octogamye .
Whi shulde men than speke . of hit vilaynye .
Loo here . the wise kyng Dau salamon
I trowe that he had wyfes moo þan oone .
As wolde god it leful were to me .
To be refresshed half so wele as he .
Which ȝifte of god had he . for al his wyfes
No man hath such that in the worlde alyve is
God wote this noble . kyng as to my wytte .
The first nyȝt had mony a mery fitte .
Whit iche of hem so wele . was hym on lyve .
Blessid be god that I haue . weddid fyve .
Welcome the sext whan that eủer/re he shal
For soth I . wil not kepe me . chast in al
When my housbond is fro the worlde ygone .
Som cristen māmn shal wedde me . anone .
For than the Apostle . seith that I . am free .
To weddyn a goddeshalf where it liketh me .
He seith that be . weddyd is no synne .
Bett̉er/re is to be weddyd . than to brenne .
What rekketh me þogh folk sey vilainye .
Of shrewyd lamech and of his bigamye .
I wote wele . Abraham was an holy man
And Iacob . eke . as ferre as I here can
And ech of hem . had wyffes mo þan two
And mony an other holy man also .
Where can ȝe sey in any man age .
That hie god defendid any mariage .
By expsse worde . I pᵃy ȝoᵘ telle it me .
Or where cōmmᵃunde he virginite .
. I . wote . as wele . as ȝe it is no drede .
Thapostle . whan he . speketh of maidenhede .
He seid that here of pcepte . had he none .
Men may concele a wōmman to be . one .
But concelyng is no cōmmaundement
He put it in oure owne Iuggement
For had he cōmmaundement maydenhede .
Than had he dampned weddyng wᵗith outen drede
And certis ȝif there no . sede were . sowe .
Virginite than wher of shuld growe .
Poule durst not cōmmaunde at the lest
That thing that his maist̉er/re . ȝaf nōm hest
The spere . is sette . vppon virginite .
That who may who renneth best late see .
But this worlde is noȝt ytake . of eủer/rey wight
But ther that god wole ȝef hit of hit myght
I wote wele . that thapostle . was a maide .
But neủer/retheles þogh he wrote . or saide .
He wolde that euery were such as he .
Al nys but concele . to virginite .
And for to bene a wiffe . he ȝaf me leve
Of indulgence so is it no repreve .
To wedde me . if that my make dye .
With outen excepciou of bigamye .
And al hit is good no wōmman for to touch
He mente . as in his bed or in my couch
For ꝑper/paril is both fire . and tow to assemble .
Ȝe knowe . what this . ensample . may resemble .
This is al and so . he helde . virginite .
More . ꝑper/parfite . than weddyng in freelte .
Freelte clepe . I but that I am she .
Wolde leden al hir lyfe . in chastite .
I graunt hit wele . I ne haue no enuye .
Thogh maidenhede . preferre . bigamye .
Hit liketh hem to be clene . in body ⁊and gost
Of myn estate . I wil not make my boste .
Full wele ȝe knowe alorde in his housholde .
Hath noȝt eueri vessel of gold
Some bene . of tree . ⁊and don hir lorde . ʆser/siruise
God clepith to hym . folke in sundry wyse .
And either haith of god a ꝓproper ȝifte .
Some this some that as hym liketh shifte
Virginite is grete ꝑper/parfeccione .
And continence eke with deuociou
But crist that of ꝑper/parfecciou is welle .
Badde noȝt eủer/rey wight he shulde selle .
Alle that he hadde and ȝif it to the pore .
And in such wise folowe hym and his lore .
He spake to hem that wolde . lyven ꝑper/parfitely
Lordes by youre leve that am not I .
I wil bistowe . alle my age .
In the actis . and fruyt of mariage .
Telle me also . to what conclusion
Wer menbres . made of gnacion
And so ꝑper/parfite wise . a wriȝt ywroȝt
Trusteth riȝt wele thei were not made for noȝt
Glose who so wole . ⁊and sey both up ⁊and doun
That thei wer makid for purgacioun
Of vryne and oth̉er/re thinges smale .
Was eke to knowe a female from a male .
And for non other caus . say ȝe no
The exꝑper/parience wote it is noȝt so .
So that the clerkes be wᵗith me wrothe .
I sey thus thei maked bene for both
That is to seyn for office ⁊and for eese .
Of engendur derwe noȝt god displese
Whi shuld men ellis in hir bokes sette .
That men shuld ȝelde to his wiffe his dette .
Now wherwith shulde he payen his payment
Ȝiffe that he . ne vsed his sely Instrument
Than were . thei made . vppon a creature .
To purge vryne . and eke . for engendur
But I sey not that euery wight is holde .
That haith suche . harneys as I of tolde .
To gone and vsen hem in engendur
Than shulde men taken of chastite no cure .
Crist was a maide . and shapen as a man
And many aseint syn the . worlde bigan
Ȝet lyved thei eủer/re in ꝑper/parfite . chastite .
I nyl envye . no virginite .
Lete hembe brede of pure . whete seede .
And lete vs wyffes ete barly brede .
And ȝit with barly brede . marke telle can
Oure lord refresshid many a man
In such astate . as god haith clepid vs
I wil preserue I am noȝt precious
In wifhode wole I . vsen my instrument
As frely as my maker hath it sent
Ȝif . I . dangerous be god ȝif me sorow
Myn . housbond shal it haue . both eue ⁊and morowe .
Whan that hym luste . come . forth ⁊and pay his dette .
An housbond wole I haue . I wole not lette
Which shal be bothe . my dettoure . ⁊and my thralle .
And haue his tribulacion with alle .
Vppon his flessh while that I . am his wyffe
I haue the pouere . duryng al my lyffe
Vppon his ꝓproper body and noȝt he .
Right thus theapostle . tolde hit vn to me .
And bad oure . housbond . to loue . vs wele .
Al this sentence me . liketh euerydele
Vp starte the ꝑper/pardonere and that anone .
Now dame qd he by god and by seint Iohn
Ȝe been a noble . pchoure in this caas
I was abouten to wedden a wiffe alas
What shuld I by it on my flessh so dere .
Ȝit had I leuer wedde no wiffe . to ȝeere .
Abide qd she . my tale is noȝt begonne .
Nay þᵘ shal drynk of a noþ̉er/re tonne
Or that I go . shal sauer worse than ale .
And whan I haue . ytolde the forth my tale .
Of tribulacion in mariage .
Of which I am expert in al my age .
This is to sayn my self hath bethe . whippe .
Than maiste þᵘ chese . whether þᵘ wilt skippe .
Of thilke tonn that I shal a broche .
Beware . of it or þou to nye aproche
For I shal telle ensamples mo þan ten
Who so wil not be ware . by other men
By hym shul other men correctid be .
This same . wordes . wrote ꝓprotholome .
Rede in his almageste . and take hit there .
Dame I wolde pᵃy ȝow . ȝif youre wille were .
Said this ꝑper/pardoner as ȝe bigan
Telle forth youre tale sparith for non man
And telle vs ȝong men the pᵃctike .
Gladly qd she . syn hit may ȝow lyke .
But that I . pᵃy ȝow al this . compagnye .
As take noȝt a griffe . of that I saye .
For myn entent is noȝt but for to pleye .
I . ȝow pᵃy sirs greueth not ȝoᵘ what I seye .
Now ʆser/sir than shal I telle forth my tale .
As euer mote I drynk wyne . or ale .
I . shal sey sothe . tho housbondes þᵗat I hadde .
As thre of hem were goode and two . were . badde .
The thre men weren gode . ⁊and riche . and olde .
Vnnetthes myght thei the statutes holde .
In whiche thei were ybounden to me .
Ȝe wote wele . what I mene . of this ꝑper/parde .
As helpe me god . I laughe whan I . thynke .
How pitously a nyght I made hem swynke .
But by my fay I tolde it for no stoure .
Thei hadden . me ȝiffen . hirland ⁊and eke hir tᵉsoure .
Me nedith noȝt to . don lenger diligence .
To wynnen . hir loue . or don hem reuerence .
Thei loued me so wele . bi god aboue .
That I ne tolde . no dente . of hir loue .
Awyse . wōmman wil besy hir eủer/re in oone .
To gete hir loue . ȝei there she haith none .
But sith I hadde hem holy in to myn honde .
And sithen that thei hadden y ȝiffen me alhir londe
What shuld I take . kepe hem for to plese .
But hit were . for my profet or for my eese .
I set hem so on werke . by my fey
That many a nyght thei song weylawey
The bakou was not fet for hem I trowe .
That som men han in Essex at Donmowe .
I gouerned hem . so wele . after my lawe .
That eche of hem ful blisful was and fawe .
To brynge me . gay thinges fro the feire
Thei were gladde . whan I spake . to hem faire
For god it wote . I chidde hem spitously
Now herkeneth how I bare me ꝓproporly
Ȝe wiffes than kan vnderstounde
Thus shal ȝe speke ⁊and bere wrong anhonde .
For half so boldely can ther no man
Sweire and lie as a wōmman can
I sey not this by wyffes that bene wyse .
A wyse wyffe . if that she . conne her goode .
Shal bere hym on hond . the cowe is woode .
And take wyttenesse . of hir owne . mayde .
Off hir assent but herken how I seide .
Sir olde caynard is this thyn aray
Why is my neighebours wyf so gay
She is honoured oủer/re al wher she goth
I sitte at home . I haue no thrifty cloth
What doste þoᵘ at my neighbours hous
Is she so faire . art þᵘ amerous
What rowne ȝe . with ȝoᵘur maiden bndicite .
Sir olde lechour lette thi Iapes be .
And ȝiff I haue . a gosshep or a frende .
With outen gilt ȝe . chiden as a fende .
Ȝiff that I walke . or pley vn to his hous
Þoᵘ comest home as dronken as a mous
And prechest on thi bench wᵗith euyl preve .
Thow saist to me . it is a grete . myschefe .
To wedde a poure wōmman for costage .
And ȝif she be riche . for grete parage .
Than saist þᵘ that it is a turmentrie
To suffren hir pride . and hir malencolie
And ȝif she be faire . þᵘ verrey knaue .
Þᵘ saiste . that euery holoure wole hir haue .
She may no while in chastite abide .
Thou saiste . som folke . desire . vs for richesse .
Some for oure shappe . ⁊and some for oure fairnesse .
And some for she . can either syng or daunce .
And some . for gentilnes of daliaunce .
Some for hir handes ⁊and hir armez smale .
Thus goth al to the . deuel . by thi tale .
Thou saist men may not kepe a castel walle .
Hit may so long assailed be oủer/re alle .
And ȝif she be foule . þᵘ saist that she .
Couetith euery man that she may se .
For as a spaynal she wole on hym lepe .
Til that she fynde . some man hir to chepe
Ne none so gray goose goth in the lake
As þᵘ saiste þᵗat wole ben with outen make .
And saiste it is an harde thing for to holde .
A thing that no man his thankes wolde
Thou saist thus brothel whan þᵘ gost to bedde .
And that no wise wōmman hath no nede to wedde .
Ne no man that entendeth in to heuen .
With wilde thounder dynt and fyrye leuene .
Mote thi wikked nekke be to broke .
Þᵘ saist that droppyng houses ⁊and eke smoke

(base) The teeris borste out of hir eyen two
(base) And seyde goode fader shal I dye
(base) Is ther no grace is ther no remedye
(base) ¶ No certes deere doghter myn quod he
(base) ¶ Thanne yif me leyser fader myn quod she
(base) My deeth for to compleyne a litel space
(base) For pardee Iepte yaf his doghter grace
(base) For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas
(base) And god it woot no thyng was hir trespas
(base) But for she ran hir fader for to se
(base) To wel come hym with greet solempnytee
(base) And with that word she fil aswowne anon
(base) And after whan hir swownyng is agon
(base) She riseth vp and to hir fader sayde
(base) Blessed be god that I shal dye a mayde
(base) Yif me my deeth er that I haue a shame
(base) Dooth with youre child youre wyl a goddes name
(base) And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
(base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil
(base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng

div.l: (base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius
(base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale
(base) ¶The myry talkyng of the hoost to the Phisicien and the Pardoner
(base) Et Incipit Prologus de la Pardoner cum fabula sua .
(base) Oure hoost gan to swere / as he were wood
(base) Harrow quod he / by nayles and by blood
(base) This was a fals cherl / and a fals Iustise
(base) As shameful deeth / as herte may deuyse
(base) Come to thise Iuges / and hir Aduocatz
(base) So falle vpon his body and his bones
(base) Algate this sely mayde / is slayn allas
(base) Þe deuyl I bekenne him al at ones
(base) Allas / to deere boghte she beautee
(base) Wherfore I seye alday / that men may se
(base) That yiftes of Fortune / and of nature
(base) Been cause of deeth / to many a creature

div.l: (base) Her beaute was her deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) Of bothe yiftes / that I speke of now
(base) But her of wil I not ꝓprocede as now
(base) Hir beaute was hir deþ I dar wel sayn
(base) Men han ful ofte / moore for harm than prow
(base) Hir beaute was hir deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) ¶ But trewely / myn owene maister deere
(base) This is a pitous tale / for to heere
(base) But nathelees passe ouer is no fors
(base) I pray to god / so saue thy gentil cors
(base) And eek thyne vrynals / and thy Iurdones
(base) Thyn Ypocras / and eek thy galyones
(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan
(base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme
(base) But wel I woot thow doost myn herte to erme
(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle
(base) By corpus bones / but if I haue triacle
(base) Or ellis a draghte / of moyste and corny ale
(base) Or but I heere anon / a murye tale
(base) Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde
(base) ¶ Thow beel amy / thow Pardoner he sayde
(base) Tel vs som myrthe / or Iapes right anon
(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake
(base) I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a Cake
(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
(base) ¶ Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal here
(base) But in the cuppe wol I me bithinke
(base) ¶ I graunte ywis quod he / but I moot thynke
(base) Vpon som honeste thyng whil that I drynke

div.l: lOrdynges qd he in chirch whan I pche
I peyne me to haue an hawten . spech
I rynge it of as rounde as goth a belle .
For I can all by rotte þat I telle .
My teme is alway one and eủer/re was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Firste I . ꝓpronounce whens þᵗat I . come
And than my bulles shew all ⁊and sōmme
Oure liege lordes seale on my patent
That shew I first my body to warent
That no man be so bolde prest ne clerk
Me to disturble of cristes holy werk
And after that telle I forth my tales
Bulles of popes and of cardinales
Of patriakes and bisshopes I shewe
And in latyn I speke wordes a fewe
To saver with my pdicaciou
And for to stir men to deuocion
Then shew I . forth my long cⁱstall stones
Y crōmmed full of clothes ⁊and of bones
Relykes þei bene as wene þei ychone
Than haue in latou a shulder bone
Which þᵗat was an holy Iewes shepe
God men sey I . take at my wordes kepe .
Ȝif that this bone be wasshen in a welle
Ȝif cowe or calf or shepe or ox swelle .
That any worme hath ete or stonge
Aboute the hert or ellys þe longe
And it is hole anone and forthermore
O Pokkes and of scabbe ⁊and of eủer/rey sore
Shall eủer/rey shepe be hole þᵗat of this welle
Drynkez a draught take hede what I telle
Ȝif that þe goode man þat þe bestis oughe
Wole eủer/rey woke or þᵗat cokke hym crowith
Fastyng drynke of this welle a draught
As thilke holy Iewe oure eldres taught
His bestes and his stoure shall multiplie
And sirs also hit helith Ielousie
As þough a man be fallen in a ielouse rage
Lete maken with þis water his potage
And neủer/re shall his wyfe mys trust
Þough he þe south of hir defaute wyst
All had she taken freres tweyn or thre .
Here is a myteyn eke þat ȝe may see .
He þat his hond wil put in this myteyn
He shall haue multiplying of his greyn .
Whan he hath sowen . be hit Whete or otes
So þᵗat he bring me goode penys or ellis grotes
And men ⁊and wōmmen oo thing I warne ȝow
Ȝif any wight be in this chirch now
That haith done synne horrible þᵗat he
Dar not for shame of hit shryuēm be
Or any wōmman be so ȝong or elde
That hath made hir housbond cokewolde .
Such folke shall haue no pouer ne no gᵃce
To offre to my relikes in this place
And who so fyndeth hym oute of such blame .
Thei wole come vp ⁊and offre in goddes name
And I assoile hem by the autorite
Such as my bulle. was gᵃunted to me .
By this gawde haue I wonen eủer/rey ȝer
An hundreth marke syn I was ꝑper/pardoner
I stond ylyke a clerk in my pulpite
And shewe lewed peples synnes I sette
I pche . so as I haue lered before .
And telle an hundreth Iapes more
Than peyne I me to stretche forth þe nekke
And est and west vpon þe peple I bekke .
As doth a dowue . sittyng on a berne .
My hondes and my tonge . gone . full ȝerne
That is ioy to se my besynes
Of euerich and such cursidnes
Is all my pchyng for to make hem fre .
To ȝif hir pans ⁊and namely to me .
For myn entent is noght but for to wynne
And no thing for correcciou of synne .
I rekke neủer/re whan þat þei bene beryed
Þough þat hir soules goone on blakburied
For certes many a pdicaciou
Cometh ofte tyme euyl entēmciou .
Some forth for plesaunce of folk ⁊and for flaterye .
To ben avanced by ypocricey
And some . for veinglorie . and some for hate
For whan I dar note by other wayes debate .
Than will I styng hem with my tong smert
In pching so þat he shall no stert
To bene diffamed falsely so þᵗat he
Hath trespasyd to my bretheren or to me .
For þough I telle . not his ꝓpropr̉er/re name
Men shall wele knowen þat it is þe same
By some signe and other cⁱcumstances
Thus smyte I . folke . þᵗat doth hus displesances
Þus spitte oute I myn venym . vnder hew
Of holynes to semyn holy ⁊and trew
But shortely myn entent I will deuyse .
I pche of no thyng but of couetyse
Þ̉er/refore . my teme is ȝit and eủer/re was
Radix omniu malorum est cupiditas .
Thus can I . pch aȝens þe same vice .
Which þᵗat I vse . and þat is Auarice .
But þough my self be giltife in þᵗat synne
Ȝit can I . make other folke to wynne
From auarice ⁊and sore hem repente
But þᵗat nys not my principale entent
I pche not but for couetise .
Of this mater it aught I now . suffice .
Than telle I hem ensamples many one .
Of olde stories long tyme agoone
For lewed peple . louen tales olde .
Which thinges con þei report ⁊and holde .
What trow . ȝe that whiles I . may pch
And wynne . gold ⁊and silủer/re for to teche .
Þat I . will lyfe in pouert wilfully
Nay nay I þoght it neủer/re trewly
For I will preche and begge . in sondry londes
I will not do no labour with my hondes
Ne make baskettis and lyfe þ̉er/re by
By caus I will not leven ydelly
I will none of þe apostles conterfete
I wole haue money malte and chese . ⁊and whete
Al were it ȝeven of the pourest page .
Awther of þe porest vidow in a . village .
Al shuld hir childrene . sterfe . for famyne .
Al I . wil drynke . þe licorest of the wyne
And haue I . a ioly wenche . in eủer/rey towne .
But herkeneth lordes my conclusione .
Ȝour likyng is þᵗat I shall telle a tale .
Now haue I . dronken a draght of corny ale .
By god I . hope I shall telle ȝoᵘ a thyng
That shall by resoun be at your lykyng
For þough my self be a full vicious man
A morale tale . ȝet I . ȝoᵘ telle can
Which Iames went to pche . for to wynne .
Now holdeth ȝour pees my tale I wil begynne
IN flaundres whilome was a companye
Of ȝong men þᵗat haunted folye .
As hasard ryot stewes ⁊and tauernes
Harpes ribibes lutes ⁊and geternes
Thei dauncen ⁊and playn at þe dys nyȝt ⁊and day
And ete also oủer/re þat hir myȝt may
Thorgh which þei do þe deuel . sacrifice .
With in þe deueles temple in sondry wyse .
By suꝑper/parfluite abhominable .
Here . othes ben so grete and dampnable .
That is grisely for to her hem swere .
Our blissed lordis body þei to tere .
Hem þought Iewes rent hym noght y nowe .
And ilke of hem . at other synne lowth
And riȝt anoone . come in þe tomblisters
Fetys ⁊and smale . and ȝong fruterers
Syngers wᵗith harpers bavdes ⁊and wafres
Such by verray the deuels officers
To kyndle and blow þe fir of lecherie
That is annexid to glotonye .
The holy writte . take I to wyttenes
That lecherie . is in wyne ⁊and in dronkenes
Loo how þᵗat dronken . loth vnkyndely
Lay by his doghters twe vnwyttyngly
So dronken . he was he nyst what he wroght
Herodes who so hath þe stories sought
When he of wyne was replete . at his feste
Right at his owne table ȝaf he his heste
To sleen þe baptist Iohn ful gilteles
Senek seith a good worde douteles
He seith he can no difference fynde .
Bytuyx a man þᵗat is oute of his mynde .
And a man þat is dronkenlew
But þat wodenesse is fallen in a shrew .
ꝐPer/Parseuerez lenger þan doth dronkenes
O glotonye full of cursednesse .
O caus firste of oure confusion .
Originale of oure dampnacion .
Til crist had bought vs with his blode agayn
Lo how der shortely for to sayn
A bought þe was þe cursed vilanye .
Corrupt was al þis worlde . þurgh glotonye .
Adam oure fader and his wyfe also .
Fro paradyse . to laboure . and to woo .
Were . drevyn fro þat wyse it is no drede .
For whiles þat Adam fasted as I rede .
He was . in ꝑper/paradyse . and whan þat he .
Ete of þe fruyte defendid on þe tre .
Anone he was oute cast to woo . ⁊and peyne .
O glotony on þe wele aght vs pleyne .
O wist a man how . many maladies
Folowith of excesse . and of glotonyes
He wold bene þe more . mesurable .
Of his diete sittyng at his table .
Alas þe shorte throote þe tendre mouthe
Maketh that Est ⁊and west north ⁊and south
In erth ⁊and eyre . in water . men to synke
To geten a glotou deynte mete ⁊and drynke
Of this mater O poule wele can ȝoᵘ trete
Mete vn to wombe ⁊and wombe eke vn to mete
Shall god destroie . both as Poule seith
Alas a foule thing it is by my feith
To say this worde and fouler is þe dede
Whan men so drunken is of þe whyte ⁊and reede
That of his throte he maketh his pryuete
Thurgh thilk cursid suꝑper/parfluyte .
The apostle . wepyng with pitous vois .
Ther ben enmys of cristes crois
Of which þe ende . is . deth womb is hir god .
O womb o bely o stynkyng cod
Fulfilled of dong and of corrupciou
At either ende . of þe . foule . is the sesou
How grete cost and labour is to fynde .
Thes cokes how þe stampe streyne ⁊and grynde
And turne substance in to accident
To fulfille . all þi laboures talent
Oute of þe harde bonys knokke þei .
The mergh for þei cast not away
That may go þorgh þe golet soft ⁊and swote
Of spycerie . of leves barke . ⁊and rote .
Shal bene . his sawce . y made . be delyte
To maken hym ȝit a new appetite .
But certes he þat haunteth such delites
Is dede whilest he . lyfes in to vices .
A lecherie . þing is wyn ⁊and dronkenesse .
It is full of stryuyng ⁊and of wretchednes
O dronken men disfigured in thy face .
Foule is thi breeth foule art þᵘ to enbrace .
And þogh þi dronken noyse . sowneth þe sowne .
As þogh þou seidest ay sampson sampson .
And ȝit god wote . sampsou dronke neủer/re no wyne .
Þou fallest as it wer a dronken swyne .
Thy tong is lost and all þi honest cure .
For dronkenes is verray sepultur
Of māmnes wytte and his discrecion .
In whome þat drynke . hath dominaciou
He can no councele . kepe it is no drede .
Now kepe ȝoᵘ fro þe white ⁊and fro þe reede .
Namely from þe white wyne . of lepe .
That is to selle in fissh streete ⁊and in chepe .
This wyne . of spayne crepit subtilly
Þan other wynes grovyng fast by
Of which risith such fumosite
That whan a man hath dronken a draght or three
And weneth þat he be . at home in chepe .
That he is in spayne . riȝt at þe toun of lepe .
Noght at þe Rochell ne at Burdeux toun
And þan wole þei say sampson sampson .
But herkenyth lordynges oo worde I ȝoᵘ pᵃy
That all þe . soủer/reane . actes dar I say
Of victories in olde testamēmt
That þorgh verray god þᵗat is oīmpotent
Were ydon in abstinence ⁊and in pᵃiere .
Loketh þe bible . ⁊and þer may ȝe it lere .
Loketh attila . þe grete conquerour
Deyd in his slepe . with shame ⁊and dishonour
Bledyng at þe noyse in dronkenesse .
A capitane shuld lyve . in soburnes
And oủer/re all thise . avyse . ȝoᵘ riȝt wele .
What was cōmmaunded vn to lamuel .
Not samuel . but lamuel . say I
Redith þe bible and fyndeth hit expssely
Of wyne ȝevyng of hem þᵗat ar iustice .
No more of this for it may suffice .
And now þᵗat I haue . spoken of glotony
Now will defende ȝoᵘ hasardye .
Hasarde . is þe verray moder of lesynges
And of disceyte . cursid for swerynges
Blaspheme of crist manslaghter ⁊and wast also .
Of bataile and of tyme . ⁊and of forther mo .
Hit is repreef and contᵃrie to honour
For to be holden . a comyn hasardour
And eủer/re þe hier he is of estate .
The more he is holden desolate .
Ȝif that a pⁱrince vse hasardie
In all goủer/renaunce and policie
He is all be cōmmyn opinione
Holde þe lesse in reputaciou
Stilbon þᵗat was holde a wyse embassatour
Was send in to corinth with full gret honour
Fro calydonye . to make hem allyance
And whan he come happed þis chaunce
That alle þe grettest þᵗat were of þᵗat londe .
Pleyng at hasard he hem fonde .
For which as sone as þᵗat myght be .
He stale hym home aȝen to his contre .
And seid þer I wole not lose my name
I wold not take on me so gret diffame
For to allye ȝoᵘ to non hasardours
Sendeth other wyser embassatours
For by my trouth me were lever dye .
Than I shuld ȝou to hasardours allye .
For ȝe þat bene . so glorious in honores
Shall neủer/re allye ȝoᵘ with hasardoures
As my wille . ne as by my trete
This wyse . philosophres saide .
Loke eke . that þe kynge . Demetreus
The kyng of Partes . as the kyng seith thus
Seint hym a peir of dyse . of gold . in scorne .
For he had vsed hasardrye . þer by forne .
For which he held his glorie . and his renoun
For no value . of reputacione .
Lordes myght fynde . other man playe .
Honest ynow . to dryve þe day a waye .
Now wole I speke . of othes fals ⁊and grete .
A worde or twoo . as oth̉er/re bokes entrete .
Grete sweryng is a thyng abhominable .
And fals sweryng is moche mor reprouable .
The hye god forbarreith sweryng at all
Wittenes of mathev . but in espāmle .
O sweryng the holy ieromye
Thou shalt swere soth þin othes ⁊and not lye
And swere in dome . ⁊and eke in riȝtwissenes
But ydell sweryng / is a cursidnes
Behold ⁊and see þᵗat . in þe first table
Of hye goddis hestes honorable .
How þᵗat two hestes of hym is þis
Take noȝt my tale in idelnes amys
Loo rather he forbedith such sweryng
Than homicide . or any other thyng
I say as thus by ordre . it stondith
This knowith þat his hestes vnderstondeth
How . þᵗat þe secound heste . of god is that
And forther oủer/re I will the telle . alle platte .
That vengeaunce shall not parte frōm his hous
That of his othes is so outerageous
By goddis pcious hert ⁊and his nayles
And by his bloode þat is in hailes
Seuen is my chāmnce ⁊and his fyfe ⁊and three
By goddis armes ȝif þᵘ falsely pley me
This dagger shall þorgh thyn hert goo .
This fruyte cometh or þilke bones twoo
For sweryng Ire falsenes homicide .
Now for þe loue of criste þᵗat for hus deyde .
Leuyth ȝour othes both grete ⁊and smale .
For I shall telle ȝoᵘ a mvelous tale .
These ryotours of which I ȝoᵘ telle
Long erst or pryme rong any belle .
Were sette in a tauerne to drynke .
And as þei . satte þei seid þei herd a belle clynke .
Byfore . a corps was caried to his grave
That one of hem . gane calle to his knave .
Go bet quod he . and aske redyly
What corps is þat passith forth by
And loke þou reporte his name wele
Sir qd þis knave it nedith neủer/re adele .
Hit was me told er ȝe come here two owres
He was parde an olde . felaw of youres
Al sodenly was he slayn to nyȝt
For dronken as he sat vppon his bench vp right
Ther come a prevy thefe . men clepith deith
That in þis contrey all þe peple sleigh
And with his spere he smote his hert a two
And wente his wey wᵗith outēm wordes mo
He hath a þosand slayn þis pestilence .
And maister er ȝe come in his psence .
Me thinketh þat it were necessarie .
For to be ware . of such an adủer/resarie .
Beth redy for to mete hym eủer/remore
Thus taught me my dame I say nomore .
By seint marie said þis tauerner
The child seith soth for he haith slayn to ȝer
Hens but a myle . wᵗith in a grete village .
Both man ⁊and wōmman childe ⁊and page .
I trowe his habitaciou be there .
To ben avised grete wisdome . it were .
Or þat he did a man dishonour
Ȝe goddes armes qd this ryotour
Is it such ꝑper/paril . wᵗith hym for to mete
I shal hym sech by stye ⁊and by strete
I make a vow by goddes digne bones
Herkeneth felawes we three . bene al ones -
Lete ych of hus hold vp hond to other
And eche of hus bycome other brother
And we wil sle þis fals traytour deth .
He sall be slayne he þat so mony sleth
By goddis dignite er it be nyght
To gedre han þes three her hertes plight
